I’ll be returning my copy to Amazon.If you decide to purchase anyway, may the odds be ever in your favor.

review_title: Another great game for hours of fun with the family
review_description: Another great game for hours of fun with the family.Synopsis: You are a dragon flying around trying to not hit another dragon, or fall off the map.The game is a tile placement game. Simple as that. Each tile has a set of paths on it. When you place a tile in front of your dragon marker you follow the path you create. Each tile can be rotated to change the outcome of the placement. If you hit the edge of the map, or another dragon you are dead and leave the game, returning your unused tiles to the draw pile.The game is perfect for 4-8 players. Any less and it is still fun, just not as enjoyable in my mind.This is a great game for kids, or to break the ice in a gaming night event. With game play limited to about 30 minutes for a full game, you can easily complete 1-3 rounds in an hour as a warm up to a bigger more involved game.

This is one of the most beautifully, simplistic, and fun games, with a ton of replay value, that I have every played!Of all the games that I have - everyone (friends and family) love to play this game and is requested every time we get together.The artwork on the box, game board, tiles, instructions, dragons is beautifully drawn. The rules are simple, you have 3 tiles in hand (different paths are drawn on them), place a tile, more your dragon along the path, and be the last dragon left on the board.The more people that play (8 total) the more fun and strategy there is to keep on the board without falling off (due to your tiles paths or someone else's connecting path) or colliding with another dragon. The games are also fairly quick so if you fall off the board early it's not a long wait to play again.This is an amazing, simplistic, beautiful, high replay, very fun game for casual and hardcore board gamers of all ages!Comparison to its sister game: Tsuro: Of The Seas / Why I bought Tsuro:TGOTP over T:OTS~ 'Of The Seas' plays just like Tsuro:TGOFP but has some new elements. With artwork just as beautiful the board which is a little bigger (7x7 grid). There are sea monsters that roam the seas, able to remove the paths that they cross & can destroy you if you collide with them.I bought 'The Game Of The Path' over 'Of The Seas' because 'Of The Seas', I think, added too many mechanics (the sea monsters - that move around the board - every single time a player moves based on a dice roll) can knock you out of the game extremely early (especially with more people playing) and removes path tiles that they land on top off - allowing new tile to be placed there: This extended the play time a lot - so if you got knocked out of the game early on, you would be waiting a while before you could play again. You can still play the 'TGOTP' way with 'OTS' by removing the monsters and only playing with a (6x6) grid, but I loved 'TGOTP's artwork more and (since I play with a lot of people) I didn't want that extra wait variable time.

Got this game because I played it at a work party, and it was fun and ready to learn. I knew my kids would be able to play it, including my 8-year-old twins.My family enjoys it. It is easy to learn and easy to play. It doesn't require a ton of thought, so it is a game friends can play while talking. No complicated rules and not too much in the way of strategy.The board and pieces are constructed well and are really nice.Not recommended for people who like complicated games with lots of strategy. Recommended for people who want something fun to do while talking and hanging out

review_title: A bit too easy and a bit boring
review_description: Nothing wrong with my order, it was delivered quickly and everything was new and undamaged.  This is a review of the item specifically.We were really excited to get this game, it looked cool and we wanted more games with an eastern feel to them.  This game seemed perfect and I thought there would be some level of strategic depth to the game after reading reviews, etc.  However, after playing it once or twice it seemed like we had the game mostly figured out and it got boring pretty quickly (you can play a game in 5-10 minutes very easily).  I expected to get more play time out of this, at least with replay value but that sadly wasn't the case for me.  This game might keep the attention of someone in the range of 6-10 years a bit longer, but even then I think your money could be better spent elsewhere (perhaps I would be more happy with this game if it were in the $10-$20 range and not the $40-$50 range, it doesn't even feel like you get a bunch of pieces to make the game worth it).  If you want games with an eastern feel (of various difficulties) that have at least some replay-ability I would look into Takenoko or Lotus.  Tokaido is also more interesting and Hanamikoji is an excellent 2-player card game.

review_title: Great game for any size group!
review_description: We learned to play Tsuro while visiting family and they gifted us our own box. It is a very simple concept - start your pawn on a hashmark on the side of the board, then place tiles with pathways on them and follow the pathways. You are out if you build a pathway that runs you off the side of the board or into another pawn. The last player standing wins. A round of the game takes 10-15 minutes, but it is endlessly replayable, as every round will be different from before. It is entertaining with two, three, four, or six players (probably with five, seven, and eight as well, I just haven't played those group sizes). It fits nicely into the category of games that are fun for the whole family (to use the cliche). My 7 year old loves to play, but my husband and I can also enjoy ourselves. I highly recommend it for parents dying to get family game night out of the Candyland/Connect 4 cycle and into games a little more interesting for adults and for couples looking for a game that is as good with two people as with a bigger group.

I absolutely am in love with this game! It's a great family game. Even my 4yo can play it with minimal assistance. Easy Concept and instructions (tho were still trying to figure out the dragon card) and a great way to let kids learn critical thinking and strategy skills without the complicated rules of traditional strategy games like risk or strategy.Rounds are relatively quick so we keep it near the dining room table to break out after supper. Everyone from my grandparents to cousins now love this game and I can't wait to gift it!We can't wait to get iterations 2 and 3 now! Excellent game. I'd give it a million stars if I could.

review_title: A Delightfully Simple Addition To Any Collection
review_description: I bought this game not because it was complex or required a strategy book, but because it was beautifully simple and an elegant game to play with anyone.Some of my family members consider some of the other games in my collection daunting or draining because of the rulebook and setup times and strategy that can be involved. By getting this, it's as simple as unfolding the board, picking a colored stone, and three tiles. It's impossible to be intimidated by this game and even after dozens of rounds between family and friends it's still a great time to play and have fun with, even when I'm used to games that last more than 10 minutes. It's impressive design that none of the paths ever lead to a dead end too, although you CAN make orphaned circle paths with some select tiles, players won't ever be able to be on those paths. Every so often I'm still surprised by some of the scenarios this path building game can provide although I admit, the depth of strategy does have diminishing returns after a 15 or 20+ matches for any seasoned board game geek. :)The art and build quality are top notch, although I wish the stones/pawns were a heavier plastic. It's easy to forgive though for the enjoyment and inclusion this game has brought to me and my family members who don't normally like to play games at game night. Couldn't be happier! I highly recommend it.

I like this game... but it was over priced.Also, it is way to easy to die and so the game isn't that fun after a while.this is a game I would play maybe 5-6 times and then it would sit in my game pile forever. So enjoyable but not something I can see getting played a lot of time and definitely not something that would be picked first.Will update if things change.We also made some house rules since dying was so easy, perhaps this is something you could do.This game left me feeling like more could be added or something was missing to this game.

review_title: Easy game with some strategy, brings in non gamers.
review_description: This game is fantastic and draws people in who normally are not table top gamers.Pro: This game is extremely easy to learn, the mechanic of it is very fun,  and the more people you have the more fun it is.  The design of the game is very simple, yet very exciting and relatively fast paced.  You get through a game in 10 min and the thinking that is involved is good solid strategically thinking.Con: My only draw back with this game is how repayable it is.  You could argue that the game is different every time, and this is true from a piece, location and movement aspect, but the strategies don’t change.  Most of the fun is in your first 5 games learning a strategy that works, and from here you are never forced to re-invent yourself or adjust your main strategy.  This can get a bit boring (especially for more advanced gamers).Kids:  I have a 7 year old and a 5 year old who play and love this game.  They didn’t struggle with understanding the rules at all, and love playing the game.  They love to push their pawns towards each other and turn at the last minute (which is actually a very good strategy moving towards the middle of the board and then claiming a side to try and stall out the other players).  I would recommend it for a mature 5 year old and certainly for 6 and 7 year olds and older who like games.Overall:  This game rocks overall, the only con I had was a slight one, and people who play it once or see it played usually get excited to continue to play it.  This has become a family favorite, it is also a game we know we can break out at any time, with any crowd anywhere and have fun with.

review_title: A Really Well Designed, Simple, Fast Paced Game
review_description: It's a game that is as long or short as the time it takes for someone to choose their move. You can learn this game in less than 5 minutes, but it is extremely fun with amazing replay value. Because the tiles are randomly chosen you can actually play this game endlessly and never play the same game twice. Even small children can learn this game. It's great for squeezing into a short time span, and the more people you have the faster it plays. As each player takes their turn it limits the space on the board other people may travel, and in a short amount of time you either are the last one on the board or you get forced off the board and eliminated. Very simple, but highly addictive game. It's easy to play two or three rounds in a row without getting bored of it. The artwork of the board itself is also beautifully done, and almost frame worthy by itself. There's nothing about this game to complain about. Definitely a favorite at our house.

review_title: Wonderful game to play with all ages!
review_description: We have brought this game to play with our youth group's high school students, we have played with our 6 year old nephew, and we brought this game to play with some family internationally.  Everyone loved it! :D  It excellent for all ages. We especially like to play cooperatively where all players attempt to stay on the board to make it to the final space.  We have had success with that several times!  It is also a great game to play with bilingual communities, it is easy to learn, and learning is not contingent on accessing a lot of linguistic information. We played with friends and family who spoke other languages, and after we got the basic point across, everyone loved it.  Enjoy!

Update: I brought this with me to my friends "game night"  5 of us played, it was pretty fun specially once you can get some tactics going. Two people were forced out because of cards some one else played that sent them on a path off the board.  They too had the "wow this game looks really nice" thing going on as i unboxed it and set it up.  I just wish it came with a few more cards so no one runs out as we get close to the end of the game and there are still a few players still on the board.I bought this version over the new version because I feel it looks way better.  After playing a few rounds, i kind of wish i had the extra play options of the new version.  This game just looks good when you open it up and lay out the pieces though.  Even their catalog looks like a game book, not an advertisement.  The game board almost looks like you could frame it and hang it on a wall.  My wife and son did enjoy it, but after a few rounds they were good and we moved on to another game.  It's more fun the more people you have play.  I feel the new version would work if you only had a few people to play, gives you more to do.  If you had more people playing at once, i think this version would be better than the new version.

This game is great! I've played it among several different groups of people, and ended up playing several sequential rounds each time. I think it appeals to a lot of people because it strikes a happy middle in regards to luck and strategy. The game is also really beautiful. The board and the instructions are attractive and easy to understand/intuit, and the little stone-like player pieces are lovely too. They're made of a very smooth material that feels great, they're weighted and shaped nicely so that they stand well on the board but aren't heavy to hold/move, and they come in a really lovely variety of colors, the shades of which are a nice change from most other game pieces. Overall, the aesthetic of the game is superb.

You might be tempted to consider the more recent Tsuro of the Seas game instead, but the original has a certain charm and simplicity that is hard to argue with.  The play is fast and easy for as few as two players, and as many as eight.  Though with more than four players it's extremely strategy heavy almost from move #1.You are a Chinese dragon, flying around the board.  Your path is defined by the lines on tiles you play, of which you have three in your hand to choose, as long as there are three available to be chosen.  Each tile has two points on each of its four sides and path lines so that all eight points go somewhere.  You play the tile of your choice and follow the path thus created until it ends.  You may span multiple tiles.  If you fly off the board or crash into another player, you lose.  Last player still on the board wins.The packaging and presentation on this game is downright elegant as board games go.  I bought it as a gift for my GF so that she would have a fun, simple game that plays quickly and can be picked up by young players, and she absolutely loved the presentation.In practice, though, the game falls a little short with the ten plastic stones that represent your dragons.  The bases simply aren't large enough to give them ideal stability on the table.  And since the stones are obviously plastic and not some natural material (impractical for a production at this price point), you almost wish the stones were less authentic and more likely to remain standing up.  I'm still looking for an ideal replacement or a way to weight the bottoms of the included stones.  For now, we break out some other game's player markers.

The concepts for this game are easy to pick up. Board setup is fat and easy. The graphics and detail on everything is very well done. Overall quality of the game and pieces is pretty high compared to other games of similar price. The best thing about this game is not only the board changes every time it's played, but you as the player are the one controling the board itself. Awesome game it's become a new family favorite and played every game night.

review_title: Great for all ages, especially when warming up folks to games that aren't Monopoly and the etc.
review_description: Just a fantastic, supremely easy game to learn and finish. Games last no more than about 10 or 15 minutes, depending on how many people are playing. It will often be described as a great 'entry' and/or 'warm-up' game when you first sit down with a group of friends/family.As someone that had come from a background of Monopoly and Risk, Tsuro was one of the earliest games I recall playing that was 'unique.' Makes for a great gift for any and all ages. If you're looking for an in-depth, complicated game for a hardcore gaming group.. then keep looking. But if you want a very nice, visually appealing--yet simple game, then this is a great piece to add to anyone's game library.

review_title: Terrific, simple game to add to your game choices
review_description: If you’ve never played this, it is a great game to have ... for those down times in family gatherings, for game night warm-ups, or just to play over and over for hours. The rules are simple, the pieces and packaging are beautiful to look at. The tiles are very sturdy and the stones have such a nice feel. Even a rambunctious four-year-old can play (and win) with all ages. The games go quickly, and We find it is rare to play less than three rounds.

This game is a fun concept that's easy to learn and teach. It won't keep you entertained for hours but its an easy one to play with kids or people who don't take well to more complicated board games.However, it suffers from terrible quality. The game tiles are cheap and poorly made. After one play-through half of them were chipping along the edges. This game is absolutely not worth the $25-$30 price point it sits at. For the quality maybe $10 at best.This is my third time leaving a review of this game. So far Amazon has deleted my review twice. If they do so again its clear their review and rating system is rigged and not reliable at all. The game gets one star. Amazon gets a 0.

review_title: Easy to learn, new game every time!
review_description: This game is beautiful and giftable. Easy to learn but you won't get bored of it. I bring it to family gatherings often, as it's requested. Great for two players and even more fun with more. You can easily teach it in few minutes - basically three rules!I have gifted this game twice now, both families loved it.We've played this game with kids as young as 8 and adults over 70.A must add to your collection!

Fun togetherness the way board games used to be. This game was gift for Russian friends (in Russia).  Despite an English/Russian language difference, we four adults learned the game quickly and enjoyed ourselves. Later, their family played with their grandchildren. Four players can complete a game can be played in about 20 minutes, making re-matches easy and desirable. A quality board game that will last for years.

The game was bought as a gift for a grandson.  The game is pure strategy, and works on an unusual principle; it takes all of about 3 minutes to master the rules of play, but it'll take a lot longer to master strategy.Play is quick, with pieces moving at every turn; you can easily play several games in an evening.  The grandkids love it.

review_title: Easy to learn fun to master!
review_description: What an inventive but simple game with lots of replay-ability. The artwork is elegant and zen-like. This game is so simple a 7 or 8 year old could easily play, possibly even younger if they're sharp. However, just because a young child could play, it doesn't mean it's not fun or challenging for adults. The goal is to be the last dragon left on the board. You wind your way around the board following the path you build with the tiles. The trick is to not run yourself off the side of the board or into another dragon all while trying to thwart your opponents' dragons from doing the same. This is our favorite game this year and we have purchased it as gifts for at least 7 other families. Good, fun stuff with easy setup and quick play. Fun to fill those short down times when you need a little something to do but don't have time to break out a big game. We usually play 2 or 3 rounds in a sesion and that lasts about an hour that way. Awesome for 2 players but lots of fun with more too.

This game is a new favorite with my 9, 7, & 6-yr old. They learned the rules in 10 minutes and since the game only takes about 30 min to play, we can squeeze in a little family game time when we don't have all evening. They have since gifted it to grandparents and told friends about it. My only complaint is that there are no ridges on the board to keep the pieces in place so they tend to get bumped out of place easily, but most games are that way.

review_title: Fun game - not too intellectually challenging, but not boring at all
review_description: This is a really fun game. I really enjoy it. It has a lot of replay value, but it isn't one that I pick up often. I play maybe every few months because it is simple. I like to be challenged mentally. With that said, it is great for the younger audiences. It is very easy to learn and the quality and artwork is quite astounding!Design - 5+ starsArtwork - 5+ starsReplay value for an adult who likes being mentally challenged - 3 starsEveryone's opinions are different. I hope you truly enjoy the game if you do purchase it!

review_title: Pieces Slide Everywhere Due To Poor Design
review_description: I recently bought this game and have played a few times. Unfortunately it was not designed well. The squares that you play on has one flat side edging and one with rounded side edging, and the flat side isn’t facing down. This makes the pieces slide all over the board way too easily. If you have Carcassonne you could see what I mean. This game should have been designed with the flat side down.The game itself is pretty, but there are so many pieces that send you back to the corners that it wasn’t too fun.

review_title: Love this! Easy to understand, tricky to play!
review_description: A fun game that looks simple enough and is easy to understand, but that requires a surprising amount of strategy. In a way, it's like playing a simplified version of chess with several other people. Not nearly as challenging as chess, but you do have to plan your moves as best you can. And there are no complicated rules to argue about. I don't know who originally created Tsuro, but it's brilliant. And this particular version of the game is sturdily made, so I expect it will serve our family well for many years to come.

We played this in a game on recommendation of a game store owner. We typically play things like Catan, Dominion, Alibi, etc. This is similar in that each time the game changes based on where you place your marker. The nice thing about this game is that it is a logic game that doesn't have 20 pages of rules. It is also a pretty fast game as it only takes about 30 minutes. It allows enough players that all of my family can play at the same time. My mom is an elementary teacher and she is really excited about introducing this in her classroom as well.

review_title: Tsuro, Great Game for all Ages
review_description: I purchased the game 'Tsuro' for an upcoming family reunion. The reviews I'd researched stated the game being very easy to learn and play and they were absolutely right. The game is very easy to get into and play. There can be as few as 2 people playing or as many as 8 which makes it quite desirable for a party as you may not know how many attendees may become bored or may draw interest and this game when it's brought out so Tsuro has that aspect covered wonderfully, plus it doesn't require much effort on your part to teach to any newcomer which is something I personally love about it. It has moderate replay value, I found after 4 or 5 games we were satisfied and ready for something else. The games move at a quick pace and usually takes around 15 minutes to complete. A fun aspect is the fact that one person's tile placement may run others off the board which can create fun and comradery among those playing. Though this game is often put in the 'Toy' genre, it is a board game and will satisfy anyone from ages 8 to 80. The product is well made, colorful, and should last a lifetime. If you're looking for a board game that doesn't require effort to explain and get going, Tsuro will delight you. I give it 5 stars.

My wife and I purchased this as a birthday gift for my granddaughter. I have not had an opportunity to play the game with her yet, but I received a positive response and a big "Thank you" from her. She let me know that she has been playing with her parents and brother and they have been enjoying the game and family time together. Based on my granddaughters response, I think we made a good choice for her.

review_title: Fun, easy, low stress game play.
review_description: This is not a board game in the classical sense. I can't stress this enough. Tile placement and blind luck are the best ways to describe the game play. Some say that there isn't strategy. There is, but it is limited to holding back a more adventitious tile for late game. Playing with more people makes the game go faster, but make you feel like you have little control over. It seems more like watching the game than playing.I know  you read that and think, "Why give it 4 stars with those complaints?"  I remember a time when social interaction was something that was sought, not shied away from. When I was a kid and my parents would travel across town to play a card game or board game with their friends. It was game night and we kids had our own version of it. It was about a friendly game that you could enjoy, with people you enjoyed. Tsuro brings that back. I recommend it for that reason. If you are looking for a highly competitive game, pass this one by.

We love this game. It’s easy enough for my 5 year old to understand but still fun for everyone. The pieces are good quality and the board and box are pretty. We like that even though it’s a very simple game it can be played strategically if you are the kind of person that likes to work to knock other people off but it can also just be a game of chance.

This game is amazing in its ease of play and strategic depth. It is easy enough the I was able to teach it to my 8 year old niece, and yet it entertains me. I am usually very strategy oriented playing with table top miniature games. The game is quick (15 minutes) so multiple games can (and will) be played when you get together with friends. It plays two to eight people which make this a very flexible game.A simple description of the rules goes like this: you have 3 tiles in your hand with lines as paths for you playing figure to follow. You place the tile in front of your figure and it has to follow the path you set before it. The strategy comes in when you get close to other figures on the playing board. If you place a tile in front of your figure which is also in front of another figure, every figure must follow the path that is placed before them, even if it sends them off the board or crashing into another figure.  Lastly, if your first move is to go straight then this is called the Amanda Gambit (house rule).

Quick and easy game for the family. My boys ages 9 and 11 find this game very fun and we play it all the time. It is a time saver in that if you are looking for a game that from start to finish is 10-15 minutes and easy for anyone to understand, this is your game! We tend to play much more complicated and strategic games, but this one is not that. Quick and easy and very fun! Maximum of 4 players.

I love this game. It's simple, it's beautiful, and it's fast. It's just as fun to play with two players as it is a large group, which can't be said for a lot of my other board games. I think it would be a good choice for getting kids into board games; it makes them make their own strategic decisions and it's fast paced so they won't lose interest before it's over. That being said, it's still fun for more hardcore players that want to take a step away from Eclipse or Scythe. I highly recommend.

This game is beautifully designed and fun with lots of strategy and replay value. Games move quickly. I played it with three friends and it made great coffee table after dinner game. Each game lasted about ten minutes or so, so we played several times. One interesting aspect of the gameplay is how quickly things can change, and if you’re not paying attention your carefully placed paths can lead you right off the board!

I have owned this game for a few years.  Every once in a while I will pull it out.  It just doesn't offer that much strategy.  If you are looking for a way to kill time I would pick a different game.  It is simple to pick up and play though so it might be more fun for small kids, just not enough strategy for adults.

This game is elegant. Not just in the sense of being stylish or beautiful, but also in the sense of its simplicity. This is a game that is very easy to learn and teach to even the least nerdy person out there, but it can be played very strategically if you are a gamer who's accustomed to that sort of thing.The game's artwork and theme have absolutely nothing to do with the game, so it's a good thing that they're really really nice. The sheet of rice paper and rule pamphlet inside are a nice touch. Good job Mayfair.The game itself is so simple that you could explain the basic rules of the game in a single breath. Players start from the outside of the board and take turns placing tiles to create pathways. Avoid going off of the board and avoid crashing into other people. Done. The specifics of exactly how the game is played take another two minutes at most. Each session takes 15-30 minutes.For the gamers out there who are interested, I must say that the game is excellently designed. The game is set up such that all the players always have the same number of tiles in their hand, and there will never be a tie between two players for the victory. There are tons of different ways the tiles can rotate and the board can fill up, and yet it's very easy on the players because everything is visual. Also, since you can only have up to 3 tiles in your hand at a time, the game is so unpredictable that new players have pretty much the same chance of winning as a super-strategic player. There is no one strategy that wins all the time, and the endgame is always glorious because all the pathways connect and people go flying all over the place.

I purchased this after watching Wil Wheaton play it on YouTube (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NMtlQxJeWvc). It's extremely easy to play. You are playing cards with lines on it and then your piece moves along those lines. I wanted something that anyone could learn in 5 minutes and wouldn't take long to play. This fit the bill perfectly.What I wasn't prepared for was just how much fun it would be to play. I first tested the game on some "hardcore" tabletop gamers; the kind who love in-depth games like Warhammer. I thought for sure they'd hate it. Imagine my surprise when they wanted to play it over and over again!I then tried it with family and friends. One person in the group absolutely hates playing games. Again, absolutely everyone loved it. I think the reason for this is that although the rules are simple, keeping your player on the board takes a lot of thought and some luck. No two games are ever the same, so it's unlikely you'll get bored with it.I should also mention that the production value of the game is top notch, which is why the game is a bit pricey. Everything is extremely high quality, so it's worth every penny.It's the type of game you'll always want to bring out at parties. Guaranteed fun for all ages.

review_title: Fun, short time investment & easy to learn
review_description: My boyfriend is a huge fan of board games but I don't like lengthy ones with complex directions or strategies. I bought him this for Christmas and we love playing it. It is super easy to learn and the board and pieces are very cool. With just two people the game play time is short (10 mins or so) so we usually end up playing best of 3.

I have two game age children. We play A LOT of board and card games. This is one if our favorites. The tiles are substantial enough not to be damaged by rambunctious boys. I hope the game makers don't try to cheapen that aspect up. I really can't stress enough how the game feels well made and is beautiful and can stand up to two boys playing it. The dragon pieces are made of a pleasingly heavy resin. The tiles are heavy, thick cardboard with nice glossy printing. Oh yeah, and it's endlessly fun to play. It is really easy to learn and teach new players. Kids can play independently as long as they are old enough to remember to pick a new tile at the end of each turn. What is really fun about this game is that you can kind of mess with your opponents, but you don't always clearly see how your moves will play out. This is a great game for a group if adults, a few kids or a mix.

review_title: Easy and fun game. You never know who will win.
review_description: This is a great game for children to adult. It is easy to play. You don't need to do a lot of thinking but at the same time you never know who will win until almost the end. My grandchildren love it. Our friends love it too. This was a great addition to our game collection. It doesn't take a lot of time to play either.

review_title: A Great Game for Everyone (even board game haters)
review_description: Tsuro is a great game for everyone! It’s so easy to learn but allows each player to use as much or as little strategy as they would like.My mother is a very intelligent woman but she is the most stubborn board game player in existence. She hates all games that take more than 5 seconds to learn or more than 10 minutes to play. This makes Tsuro a great game for my family. My mom loves it because it is quick and simple. The rest of us love it because it is a fun and unique game that requires just the right amount strategical thinking.

review_title: BEWARE YOU MAY RECEIVE A LOW QUALITY FRAUDULENT BOOTLEG COPY
review_description: BEWARE YOU MAY RECEIVE A LOW QUALITY FRAUDULENT BOOTLEG COPY.I did. I have the original that I purchased elsewhere. Coup is a great game and I wanted to buy another as a gift so I ordered one from right here on Amazon. When it arrived I noticed a difference in quality from my original copy. Matching them up side-by-side I could easily tell that the one I received from Amazon didn't compare to the original and was made with cheap materials and terrible off-color printing. By all means go buy Coup because it is a great game but beware this listing. If it looks fishy call Amazon and report it. I did and they issued me a refund.

review_title: Awesome Quick-Play Strategy Game with High Repeat Play Value - Attractive to Both Avid Gamers and Casual Gamers Alike
review_description: My sister-in-law is a HUGE fan of games - especially board games. Some of them can be overly complicated and time consuming to learn and play. This game, however, is exactly what you want from a social game. It's small and easily transportable. It only takes a few minutes to explain and then only takes 10-15 minutes to play the whole game. It's a strategy game. We played 5-6 times in a row because each time we played we understood the different strategies better and it became WAY more fun. Games are short enough that it's an easy repeat-play game. The game cards are simple and beautifully designed. THIS GAME CAN STAND ON ITS OWN AND DOES NOT REQUIRE PURCHASING ANY ADDITIONAL GAMES OR EXPANSIONS. DOES NOT REQUIRE UNDERSTANDING OF OTHER GAMES IN THE SERIES.

review_title: Great game but could use some changes
review_description: So the point of this game is to be the last man standing. You can lie or tell the truth but regardless you want to be the last one left. The biggest problem I have found with this game is that no one wants to risk challenging someone because if you are wrong you lose a life. And if no one challenges anyone it basically becomes a game of who has the most tokens. So to make it more interesting we give anyone who challenges someone and is correct and extra 3 tokens and immunity to the next coup that happens. This gives people more of an incentive to challenge people

review_title: Amazon selling counterfeit Coup with defects; game unplayable
review_description: Amazon sold me a counterfeit copy.  The quality was cheap and the rulebook had spelling errors - both not serious issues.  However, one of the role cards (Assassin) had notable ink markings on the back which gave its role away, which obviously ruined the game when playing with friends.The game publisher, Indie Boards & Cards, has been helpful with its customer support but ultimately stopped its support when they identified I had a counterfeit copy, which I understand.  They recommended I complain to Amazon, which I will later today.A shame, because I've played Coup many times with my friends (with their copies) and love the game!  Looks like owning my own copy will be a few more phone calls and shipments away.  Hoping I'm not forced to pay for a replacement.

review_title: Coup is good stuff. It's a small and fun game that ...
review_description:
Coup is good stuff. It's a small and fun game that is easy to explain. If you've got a group of four to six people and you're looking for some quick fun this is a great game to go to. It's small enough to carry someplace like a cafe without much hassle, and other than the pile of coins used in the game it doesn't take up that much space on the table. As far as space, every player just needs space for two cards and their stack of coins, and perhaps the small reference sheet to remind them of what each role's powers are. Small package indeed. I have even had a good 30 minutes of fun playing this game with a total of three people. Four or more is certainly the sweet spot however.The rules are easy enough to explain and the rounds are short enough that you can introduce it to newcomers quickly, and even if they are eliminated early it won't be long before a new game begins and they can get back into it. I have found the bluffing in this game to be so enjoyable that people are often looking to play "one more round," which is a sign of a fun game. "I have the Duke so I'm going to take two coins this turn..." says a player as you stare at the Duke in your own hand... there's only two in the deck... Can he really have the other? Do you call his bluff or just let him have his two coins for now? Good times. At a price point of under $15 USD this game is hard to pass up. Because it's a bluffing game you'll want to be sure your cards don't get marked. You might want to consider sleeving them. The size is  65x100mm and the Ultrapro sleeves should fit fine. 

Ultra Pro Board Game Sleeve 65mm x 100mm - 50pk

Great little game that will generate some fun bluffing and backstabbing!

review_title: Really fun hidden role game that everyone should try.
review_description: Coup is a really fun hidden role game where you have multiple characters with different abilities they can do on their turn. Everyone on their turn can either take 1 coin, take 2 coins, use their character ability or throw a coup (given you have the coins needed) which causes another player to reveal 1 of their 2 characters....if both of your characters are revealed you're out of the game.The fun part is that no one else knows what two characters you have so you can use any ability in the game as long as no one calls your bluff. If they do call your bluff and you don't have that character then you lose a 1 of your characters. If you do have that character you reveal them, add them back to the communal deck and get a new card and the accuser loses a character themselves.Game is really fun and at the price it's currently at <$10 there's really no reason not to experience this awesome game.

review_title: Easy to play, fun, and gets everyone involved.
review_description: Bought this at the recommendation of my brother and Amazon's seller rankings as a game to help break the ice with my girlfriend's family.The rules look a bit complicated, but it helped to think of the game as a version of rock-paper-scissors that includes lying and bluffing. That is, for every card there is an opposing character that can counteract it, and you can lie about which card you have. If called out, you're "challenged" and must reveal the card. If you prove to have that card, then the player who challenged you loses one of their two characters. If you lack the character, you lose one of your characters. The last surviving player wins.Ultimately, the game is simple and fun to play. More important, everyone gets into it, even after a few glasses of wine. The game worked a treat, and we were all talking, laughing, and waiting for the next twist in game play. With the game being so simple, a lot of the entertainment lies in the twists and turns created by bluffs, challenges, and coups.Lot of fun, and each game only takes bout 15 minutes.

review_title: Tons of fun.  Cards are not standard size though.
review_description:
I missed out on the kickstarter, but grabbed a couple copies of this game as soon as it was available on Amazon.  It's tons of fun to play, even with only 2 players.  Games are short (5-10 minutes).  Compared to other fun, short games like 

Love Letter

  , there is more strategy.  It also scales up well if you have more people.  It's hard to find a bluffing game that works with less than 5 people (I'm looking at you, 

The Resistance

   and 

Werewolf

  ).The product/manufacturer descriptions do not describe this game very well.  There are 5 different cards (and 3 copies of each).  Each one gives you a special ability within the game.  You are dealt 2 cards for your hand.  The goal is to force your opponents to turn over (discard) both of their cards.  Each turn you can choose to draw money from the bank or take a special action.  Actions include spending money to force an opponent to discard, stealing money from an opponent and taking extra money from the bank.  Cards can also be used even when it's not your turn to block others from taking certain actions.  However, since all cards are dealt face down, you are free to pretend you have *any* card and can take any action you want.  If someone challenges you, you have to either show that you have the card you claimed or you are forced to turn over a card (discarding it).  If someone challenges you and you were telling the truth, they are the one who has to discard.If you were to exclusively play this game for a long time with the same group of people, it might start to get old.  However, as part of a set of games you play on game night/lunch with coworkers/whatever, you could play this for years.  Beginners can pick it up quickly and it slots nicely into small amounts of free time.The game uses a non-standard card size (65x100mm).  If you want to protect the cards from wear, you can use 

Ultra Pro Special Size Card Sleeves

   or the more expensive 

Mayday Games 7 Wonders Sleeves

  .  The cards are fairly sturdy and durable though, and the game comes in a stiff box.  I would consider sleeving the cards anyway, since any card that gets scratched or bent will essentially ruin the whole deck.  The box includes a set of reference cards and cardboard coins to use for money.  To make the game more portable, you could summarize the actions on a piece of paper and use pennies.

Our game nights start with simpler games before we get into complicated stuff like Ticket to Ride or Smallworld.  Coup is a great "opener", particularly for people who don't normally play games (you know the type, "Hey do you play games?"  "Well I play Monopoly sometimes..."  >:(  )Even though it's dead simple to learn (even non-gamers pick it up quickly) it relies a lot on each player's ability to bluff, and to call bluffs.  The basic mechanic is, 1) you can bluff your way into a better position, 2) anyone can call you out, 3) if you weren't bluffing, the accuser suffers a huge penalty, but if you were bluffing, YOU suffer a huge penalty.  So most of the game is spent with people bluffing their way into a better position, and everyone watching everyone else and paying attention to what the players are claiming they have... add in the ability to cover your tracks, and it makes for quite a lot of intrigue in such a little game.One other reason we use this as an opener is because the play time is relatively short (half an hour would be a longer game), and it's so interesting that by the end it doesn't really matter who wins, so there are almost never hard feelings.  The rules are also bulletproof: veteran gamers know that with independent games you're not guaranteed to have a perfectly functional set of rules, but that's not the case here.The art is also spectacularly good... I usually spend part of each game just looking at the art.We have also played The Resistance (same author) and it's as fun, but more complicated, and less fun art - also a great game, with a similar mechanic, but Coup gets played more.I found out about Coup through word-of-mouth and haven't been disappointed.  You won't be either if you take my word on it.

review_title: Super fun with the Right Group of People
review_description: This is a bluffing card game that reminded my family of the game BS but with a faster play time and a dystopian theme.You'll need a few learning curve play-throughs to work through questions and challenges the rule book doesn't clearly address at first. We kept having questions pop up and there was some conflict with word choice we had to address that became confusing for a few turns. (The difference between "blocking" an action and calling out a player needed to be clearer for our game)But even the learning games were fun and everyone wanted to play again. The reference cards are essential until you figure everything out, and are handy for quick reference without getting out the rule book.This sort of game relies on the people playing for fun and challenge. If you have a good group, friends and family, then it is a lot of fun. Though a group of strangers wouldn't be nearly as entertaining. Even if you know the other players, it helps to have the right mix of personalities. For example, a person who hates lying or dishonesty, another who is incapable of a lie, and someone who isn't into joking around might not make for a fun game.Otherwise this is a really good time. Quick play and fun dynamics create a fun time between bigger games or even for a few plays. For the price it's definitely worth it.

review_title: Inconsistent color on back of cards
review_description: I had played and enjoyed Coup before and thought I'd like to get my own copy and try Reformation. I bought my first copies of Coup and Reformation and the back of the cards were the same color; not even the slightest difference in shade could be seen. I ended up gifting these first copies to a friend and then decided to buy Coup and Reformation a second time to keep.I had seen reviews and posts online talking of this issue dating to since Reformation released, and I'm disappointed to discover it firsthand and that this issue has persisted for this long. For those with keen eyes, the Coup set is light gray with a slight green hue and the Reformation set is simply light gray. I have seen others online say they made contact with Indie Boards and Cards about the issue, and sadly their regular response was that these slight color differences are to be expected on different release runs and that their only recommendation (to avoid spotting the Inquisitor) is to mix the sets thoroughly so other characters from the Reformation set is included, which sounds like a half-baked solution, to be honest. I returned the 2nd copy of Reformation and tried replacing it with a 3rd Reformation set. Again, color difference.I am also uncertain if this color inconsistency is because of the Coup set, the Reformation set, or both. With this in mind, I am posting this review on both Coup and Reformation.I'm tempted to return these sets and try again, hoping to get a match like my first set of Coup and Reformation. It is disappointing that Indie would let this problem go on for so long.Come on, Indie. step up and fix this issue.

review_title: The best indie game out there!
review_description: This has been a favorite game among my circle for years. It's easy to learn, extremely replayable, and different with every group of people. I would recommend laminating the cards/getting card sleeves if you have the time, energy, and resources because if you play it as much as we do, the cards start to get worn. It's a great indie game to bring to parties that doesn't take hours to finish. Also, the expansion adds another element to mix things up for veteran players and newbies alike. I highly recommend!

review_title: Who Is Ready To Get Mad At All of Your Friends?
review_description: This game is so much fun! My group of friends always plays this at the beginning of our game nights and it breaks the ice and gets everyone in the mood for some competition. It is also really nice because the games are very short even if you are playing with the max amount of people. This is a game of lying and it is really funny to see your friends getting sneakier with each game as they are learning how to play. I like this game so much I got the expansion to it which makes it a little more intense and longer. Great for traveling and you can take it anywhere and play it anywhere. There is not many pieces either so you do not have too much to keep track of.

review_title: Cards Not Standard Size | Expansion Has Different Colored Cards. Why?
review_description: I am writing this after receiving my product in 2019.I love this game, but this is absolutely atrocious. There should be big warning in the products advertisement that states "NOT STANDARD CARD SIZE, BECAUSE WE ARE STUPID." and I shouldn't have had to delve into the reviews to find this out.Your normal card sleeves will not fit this size, and what's worse is that the card sleeves that are available are awful with the exception of one which is a clear-back sleeve which does no good if you own the expansion because the print on the back of the expansion is more saturated, making it easier to identify what cards someone might have.Honestly. Idk who the hell thought it was a good idea to make cards this size. Just keep it simple, stupid.

review_title: Coup Review by Dad's Gaming Addiction
review_description: Coup: 2-6 Players, Ages 10+, Average Play Time = 15 MinutesOne might scoff at the fact that there’s only fifteen cards in the entire game, making the content feel rather light.  On the other hand, one could come to appreciate how the game mechanics tie everything together to give it its bang for the buck.  I was admittedly skeptical at first…”$12 for fifteen cards and some plastic coins?  What gives?” Once I actually looked at the rules however and saw just how many actions you could take per turn, I began to see the possibilities both in terms of strategy and bluffing.I have a feeling that this game won’t appeal to people who don’t play a lot of Poker, or any card game for that matter that encourages people to bluff when their back is against the wall. “Coup” works better when you have a lot of people playing, but it can and does function as a two player game just fine.  My suggestion is that if you do end up playing with four or more players, that you secretly remove a card from the deck so as to prevent people from counting cards as they figure out who has who.What appeals to me most is the quick play time, what with the recent changes that have come about in my household.  “Coup” allows me to flex my brain without committing myself to an hour or two to some heavy abstract strategy game.  It also tests my memory a bit, especially when my opponents use three different character actions in one round without exchanging cards…which was the lie?  Do they know that I caught them?  What actions have I taken again and didn’t someone use the Duke recently to block foreign aid?  You see where this is going.  Anywho, I found “Coup” to be great as a filler or something to bring out at parties.  My recommendation is to give it a spin!

Oh.my.God.This game is a lot more fun than it seems. If you've ever played Resistance and enjoyed it, then this is definitely a game you should try out. The player count is less than in Resistance (2-6 players) but it definitely moves a lot faster. At first glance it seems like the rules are very complicated, but once you start playing you'll see that there is a nice flow to the game, very easy to catch on to. I even enjoy narrating the game, or even just watching and making predictions when there are more than 6 of us. Its also great that there are so many different strategies to play, and definitely very surprising to see how the game pans out. I was very pleasantly surprised with this one! Oh, and if you end up enjoying this game you definitely need to try Resistance (5-10 players). They are very different games, by the way, but similar in a few regards. Both are inmensely fun. I havent tried the expansions, but they seem killer.

This game is fun when you have like 3+ players. It's easy to learn and isn't luck-based like UNO. I also like how there aren't too many cards so I don't have to lug around this heavy box of cards and then having to shuffle and stuff. I just wish the people on the cards looked prettier because they look pretty ugly. Especially the ambassador and the captain and the duke. The assassin looks like Taylor Swift. Also, why is the Contessa wearing that necklace thing like that? Just put it on your neck already.

Great game! This was initially shown to me by my partner at a local board game bar and decided to purchase it here because it’s really fun to play. I love that it’s super easy to learn, they have cards as reminders of what each character can do and that it’s fairly small game to carry.My friends and I just all end up lying to each other then seeing who has the most courage to call each other out. Many times there’s 4 of us and somehow we’re always the duke??? There’s only 3 in the deck, haha! Fun stuff.

What a fun game!  It took a little while to get to know the characters and what their special powers are, but there is a cheat sheet provided to each player to help.  Bluffing is the key to the game...you need to have a polka face at all times.  The object of the game is to make your opponents surrender the two cards that each player is dealt....and then you become the winner.  Since your opponents do not know what characters you have been dealt...you can easily (sometimes) dupe them into thinking you are a character that you are not simply by using that polka face.The game is a lot of fun...takes maybe ten minutes a round to play...and you get better with each time you play as you learn to strategize.

Very fun game. Can be played with a lot of players and each round doesn’t take long. People may think you need to be good at bluffing, but some of the friends who can’t lie to save their lives were being very successful and winning several rounds. It’s also simple to learn game after playing just one round. Maybe 2. My parents struggle with a lot of board games unless they’re classics, but they understand this one east and enjoyed it. Rounds typically last between 5-15 min depending on how many players. Great game for its price and replay value.

review_title: One of the few available 6-player travel games that is fun
review_description: I bought this game to play while traveling with a group of 6 people.  It is really hard to find a game that is compatible with 6 players and can travel well.  While I think the ideal number is 3-4 players, this game worked out really well with the six.  It also did not take up much space in my bag.  I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because it isn't my favorite games genre; however, I have no regrets in buying it.More details:Just a quick overview of the game.  It plays quickly -- over in 15-20 minutes.  It is a game mostly built around bluffing, calling bluffs, and eventually backstabbing (or not depending on how you play).  Each player starts two character cards.  You are out once you lose both cards. The last person standing wins.The interesting aspect is that not only does each card type grant the player a special ability but that the cards are also flipped over.  Since they are hidden from the other players, you can claim to use a power to which you don't have a right.  Every turn a person has the right to challenge you.  If you aren't using a ability granted by your cards, you lose a card.  If the challenger is wrong, he loses a card.  There are also other ways to attack and defend other players using a card's special ability.  They seem pretty balanced.Overall, it is a fast-paced game.  You sort of get an idea how people like to play.  Some bluff, some don't.  You can also see some interesting natural alliances that form between people (one couple also supported each other, the other one did seemed to always attack each other).  And because the games go quickly, you have a chance for revenge.The gameplay is different with 6 players because the reserve deck is much smaller.  Almost all the card types are out, and you can't switch out as well.  So it makes it really hard to bluff and weakens some of the special abilities.  It is still fun though

One of the most straightforward games you can get, yet endlessly fun. The fundamentals of the game can be taught in minutes, but the social dynamic will keep the game interesting indefinitely. There are 6 roles, represented as cards, each with their own unique abilities. Players are dealt cards face down with remaining cards in a pool. From there you must bluff, negotiate, and strategize your way to victory. The game is for up to 6 players, and while I find the more players the better, I have played most of my games with 4 players and it does not lose its complexity.This is not a game that you would dedicate an entire night to, as rounds last anywhere from 5 minutes to 20 minutes, but I have ended up playing for a couple hours occasionally. Great game to introduce to people that do not play board games, to get a game night started, or as a casual game.

review_title: Good game but can be brutal
review_description: My family enjoys this game and we have played several times.  It is hard as the adult to play this game with your kids because you have to target people and that can be tricky especially if you have a sensitive kid.  So far everyone has been fine with that but the adults tend to target each other more to keep the peace :) Would be more fun to play with friends who are all adults.  That said my kids really enjoy the game.  We alternate between this, One Night Werewolf and Exploding Kittens.

review_title: Not Much Fun for Only Two Players
review_description: The one and only time I played this game was with one other person. It's downright boring as a two person game. It really just comes down to who can lie better and who actually has the better cards. The rounds are super quick with two people- I'm talking about maybe 5 minutes--probably less. It's not very satisfying or immersive when the two person rounds last so little time. The win doesn't feel quite as sweet.Gameplay reminds me of a more complicated version of BS. Perhaps this makes me a simpleton, but I prefer BS.Maybe with more people it could be fun, but I don't think they should advertise this as a 2-6 player game.

Fun game of deceit with low enough rules so a new player can pick it up, while still having enough to be rewarding to experienced players. There are three copies of each of six roles, and each player is dealt two roles and can use certain powers based on what roles they have, but they can claim to have a role that they don't actually have and -- unless someone calls them on it, which is risky -- they get away with it. The game ends quick enough that even if you get eliminated early, it's really not a long wait (never longer than 10 minutes, if even 5). One small issue with the game is that it's pretty risky to call someone's bluff in general (you lose one of your two lives if you're wrong), but this is integral to the nature of the game. It's not a game with a guaranteed winning strategy either, and sometimes the winner is decided by an arbitrary case of one player killing you instead of another player, leaving that other player to kill him. Overall, the game is addictively fun and requires a good amount of thought to play.

I LOVE Coup!! I first played it two years ago. It was the last week of uni. The SO were throwing us a campus-wide farewell party of sorts. Most of me mates were drunk, flying, or napping. A bunch of us got together in someone's flat, poured glasses of our preferred drinks, and pulled this out. It only took a few turns to catch up to the others, all of whom had played it plenty before.There's practically no set-up required. There's just enough of bluffing and strategy required to make it fun but not enough to be overly complex. Basically, you won't have to set apart 2-3 hours to play this game. You could play a few rounds and be done in 30 mins or go on for hours. You can play it with just two people but generally, the more the merrier. It also makes way for great banter. All in all, a great game, whether used as an ice-breaker or a bonding exercise.

review_title: Coup: strike while the iron is hot
review_description: Actual dialogue from a Coup game:"I'm the Captain. I steal two coins from you.""No you're not.""Is that a formal challenge?""No, I just know you're not the Captain.""Anyone else going to challenge? Ok, I take your coins.""You can't.""Why not?""I'm also the Captain."Coup is a bluffing game for 2 to 6 players. At its core, it's a simple matter of acquiring coins and killing all opponents with them. The rules fit on a small card: a few ways to gain coins, a couple of ways to kill, one way to steal coins, and one way to change your hand. You have at most two out of five different roles available face down in your hand, and you spend your game trying to keep your hand hidden and alive.The beauty of Coup is that even though you only have two cards with their attendant powers, you can claim to have any power you want. The only way to stop you from exercising your power is to initiate a high stakes life-and-death challenge. Either the bluffer or the challenger will lose a card in a challenge, so the heart of the game is to deduce the hidden holding of the other players, and not let them get away with the brazen bluffs that will turn the tide in their favor.As in poker, but without complicated considerations of hand strength, the quest to go to the level below your opponent gives this game bottomless depth and replayability. The powers are a carefully balanced Rock Paper Scissors, and allow any initial holding, played well, to win the game. Coup also has built-in escalation mechanisms that avoid cyclical positions and virtually guarantee all games drive to a winner.Fast games can take five to ten minutes. A particularly epic game with many players might take an hour.If there is one possible complaint, it's that multiplayer endgame scenarios can get a little complicated. If the last players' holdings are obvious, it's tempting to try to mentally play out the rest of the game before figuring out which power you need to claim to have a shot at winning. This can slow down the game tremendously. You might want to put paralyzed analyzers on the clock.Even though you can probably make your own Coup out of a deck of cards and some ordinary household items, this is a well-made game. The rule sheets for each player are clear and well organized, the octagonal cardboard coins wear well, and the cards are large and easy to read.This is well worth your gaming dollars in the $15 or even $20 range. Obsessed friends paid $50 for Kickstarter editions. I wouldn't go so far, but it comes out in virtually every boardgaming session these days.

review_title: Meets all check marks for a fun game with a small group
review_description: We played this game last night with our niece and her hubby visiting from out of state. It was a blast! They had played before. It was our first time. Took a minute for me to pick up the strategy, but was super easy to learn.Games these days usually require a lot of players to have fun. This game, I feel, is best kept at 3-5 players. Six would work too, just might be a bit much in my opinion. The games goes so quickly that it’s easy to play a lot of them. One might go so far as to say addicting and can’t stop playing “just one more”. LOL it’s a different dynamic every time cuz obviously your cards change.Truth be told...when we sat down with them to play...I thought that it was going to be stupid but wanted to be a good sport. hahaIt’s super fun and I’m buying one now for myself! We were playing with our niece’s.

review_title: What A Web We Weave When First We Practice To Deceive.
review_description: Coup is a crowd-pleaser, there's no denying. This quick, little card game handles 2 to 6 players and can be played in fifteen minutes or less, making it a great addition to game nights. It is best played with five to six playes and it's fairly easy to pick up. It also comes with six handy reference cards to make learning the game even easier.The object of the game is to bluff your way to victory. In a far-flung future where the majority of the population is poor and oppressed, only a select few wield power and wealth. You will draw two cards which you will keep secret from your opponents and you will either use their actions or CLAIM you have other cards instead so you can use their actions. The catch? If someone else challenges you and you can't show you have the character to justify the action you just took, you lose influence. If you DO have the applicable character, the person challenging loses an influence. Losing an influence is defined as you turning over one of your cards face up, thus losing access to one action. If you lose all your influence, meaning both your cards are face up, you're exiled and you lose. Be the last man standing to win.The game consists of 15 character/action cards and a bag of money tokens, as well as the six reference cards cited earlier, making it simple to cart around. Coup was a big hit at my game night, with people liking it a lot or flat-out loving it. It's a great way to practice your poker face, because you'll need a good one to win.

This game is extremely enjoyable. At first, I thought my friends wouldn't really like the game, but they surprisingly enjoyed playing. It's such an amazing and easy to learn game that my friends and I would be laughing every few minutes whenever someone made the move. Additionally, the bluffing aspect of the game made it even more challenging and enjoyable because it added a certain mystery feel to the game which made it even more fun. Overall, I really recommend that people buy this game because of how entertaining it is.

This game is like a more strategic version of the card game BS. It is about trying to be the last one standing and sometimes lying to ensure your victory. I love this game because it is simple and easy to teach. It takes 5 minutes to explain the rules to newcomers. The game itself is also quick, maybe 15 minutes per round. The game has enough strategy and luck involved to keep the game interesting. It is wonderful for groups of 4 or more.

When my parents came to visit my boyfriend and me we played this game and they loved it. English is their second language but they love all sorts of games and this one was super easy for them to learn and play. I gave it to them for the holidays and they love it. It is super small and easy to travel with and pack. It also came beautiful with no scratches or issues at all. I will likely be getting another one.

I bought this a few months ago and after playing several times with my family, we've decided that it isn't very fun. Which means we probably won't play it enough to learn all of the nuances. If you're a poker player and want a new game to practice your bluffing skills on, you might like it. I wanted to like it, I really did. But there just isn't much to it. And even with four players, the outcomes of the games are pretty predictable.

review_title: Enjoyable, Easy to Learn, and Quick
review_description: I will say the box I got was dented so I wasn't happy about that. But as far as the actual game goes, I love it. It's a really fun bluffing game. It's really easy for people to pick up on it, but you may need to do a test round or two, but those go really fast. I really enjoy playing the game. It's quick too so when you die you aren't out for an annoyingly long time. Also, I've found the people who die like to look at other peoples' cards to see what everyone else has or had. Or they'll look through the center pile.

review_title: Once the roles are memorized, could be more fun...
review_description: I purchased this game to try with my game group and family, and I was unsure what kind of results to expect.  Bluffing games are somewhat new to both of these groups, however I had heard great things about this game so wanted to try.  Unfortunately, it flopped on both fronts.  If you know you like bluffing games, as other reviews have stated then you will enjoy this game.  Both groups I tried it with found it a bit mundane, and the need to memorize the role cards to succeed made it challenging to play with people who are new to gaming or don't have time to play multiple rounds.  Overall, I think this game can work well for some people but make sure you consider how many times people will get to play it because I didn't think about the fact that it would be challenging to play with family members given the quality of being easy to learn.

review_title: Quick to learn, and fun to play!
review_description: This is a great travel game--- the box is quite small, and you can teach the game under 5 minutes. New players will have a mastery of the rules within their first couple rounds, which are quite quick. It has a high replay value despite the simple rules, because so much of what underpins the game is bluffing, 'reading' your opponents, and thinking about basic probabilities and risk. You should give it a go!

review_title: Lots of fun for a great price
review_description: I played this game at a friend’s who actually has a hobby of collecting board games and such. Dude literally has an entire 10’ x 10’ shelf that is FILLED with board games. This game is one that he said was among his favorites. It was difficult to learn, and it is one of those games that involves role play, strategy, and of course—bluffing. It took me a few play throughs to get the hang of it and learn the roles and what they do, but once I learned it was super fun and I added the name of the game to a list so I could buy it myself, which I did and am now leaving this review so that others can know how fun this game is. For a little over $13, the entertainment value for this game is awesome.

review_title: Looks good! Can hardly wait to play it
review_description: Have not played the game yet but checked all components for issues reported by other buyers. The game appears to be of good quality stock with no marks or damage with all pieces included.  The instructions seem a little confusing to read but the sample game play scenario went a long way in understanding the game and the rules.  I expect to have a lot of fun with the family and this game!Recommend purchasing the sleeves to protect the game cards. If one gets damaged, It would be very easy to identify it, thereby giving an unfair advantage.https://www.amazon.com/dp/B004VEO8P4/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_21

review_title: My favorite quick game for three or more players
review_description: I knew I was going to love this game from the first time I saw it. First, I love the Resistance Universe and am a huge fan of The Resistance. I also really enjoy card games, fast and easy games, and games that involve guessing what others are going to do and when they are bluffing.The sci-fi premise, unique flavor, and simple but addictive gameplay keep you hungry for more, round after round. The cards feature gorgeous artwork, are well constructed, and look like they are going to last quite a while unless you treat them very roughly.As others have mentioned, it's important that people get into the spirit of the game. If they never pretend to have cards they don't and always play it straight people aren't going to have as much fun. And likewise, people who aren't good at keeping track of what other people are doing or are very shy may struggle here. On the flip-side, if you enjoy the people interaction and don't take things too seriously the game is a blast, and if you are a shy person and stretch a bit while playing it could actually help you become more comfortable acting like an extrovert etc.For the price this game is fantastic. I have no complaints but one wish. I sincerely hope there is an expansion at some point with more roles, because I think that could make the game even more fun, and I just can't get enough of the Resistance Universe.

This game awesome!  I played with five other people (some of whom do not enjoy games) and everyone was entertained.  The directions are straight forward and easy to learn, all players understood what was going on before we had gotten to everyone's first turn.After each game ended, the players (ranging from teen to adult) were excited to start up another game (which is a rarity in my home).  We played for three hours before we knew it.  Some games last as little as five minutes, while other games lasted more than fifteen.Some people relied on bluffing to win, while other players won games without a single bluff.  There is a great deal of laughter when the revelation of a bluff comes to light.  Eliminated players usually enjoyed following along with the games and making their own predictions.  Eliminated players from games like Bang are usually done for the rest of the evening, as games can go on for hours, but this game is so short and simple a new round will be started before you know it (which doesn't ruin anyone's night).Coup is most certainly a must for anyone with even the slightest enjoyment for games, you and your fellow players will wonder why would didn't pick up this game sooner.

review_title: Great game, great art, fair production value
review_description: Delightful game play with intrigue, bluffing, loose alliances and inevitable betrayal, all in 10 minutes or less per round.  This game was a quick favorite at parties with friends and family.  The rules are easily understood, and there are quick reference cards for those among us with short term (card game) memory issues.There are a couple of drawbacks, mostly to the production quality of the game. First, the instructions are littered with typos. Mind you, it does not detract from the meaning but there should have been better editing. Second, the card edges started to fray within two sessions (about 10-15 rounds per session). This is disappointing for me, since the art on the cards is stunning and I was hoping they would last longer.Even with the above issues, I still highly recommend buying this card game (and perhaps laminating the cards so they last longer). The art is excellent, the play is enthralling, and the time spent with friends/family is priceless.

review_title: I have 4 copies and the expansion
review_description: I love this game anyone can play your family or friends or coworkers.  of course if you dont get extra large game card sleeves you have to rebuy but its such a deal for the hours of game play we put into this card game.  still have the first set all worn and a second with hard plastic covers and another set that was ghetto laminated with tape, and the expansion only used that one once so Its still new.

review_title: Great game for parties, easy to learn
review_description: Learn how good your friends and family are at lying to your face! This game is great at any event because it is really easy to set up and explain to new players. For experienced players, its still fun because rounds are super quick, and each game is a new experience. I love teaching it to new people, bringing it out at board game nights, slow office days, or family nights. I've played it with kids as young as 10, who get it OK but I would not recommend it for any age younger than that.

review_title: Deception, hilarity, and pure fun -- Guaranteed!
review_description: 15 total cards across just 5 roles. Each player starts with two cards face down, much like Texas Holdem. Each turn you claim to be one of the 5 roles and take the associated action. Are you bluffing or trying to sell a double bluff? It doesn't end there. Many of the actions have counter-actions that can, in turn, be bluffed or double bluffed. Lie, deceive, fabricate, misrepresent, prevaricate, <insert synonym(s) here>. Then do it again and again. If you get caught lying, you lose one of your cards. If you incorrectly accuse someone of lying, you lose one of your cards. You can also lose a card via a coup or assassination. Once both cards are gone, you're out of the game. The last player standing is the winner.Coup is fast-paced, easily accessible, surprisingly replayable, full of player interaction and droll banter. It's a social, bluffing masterpiece!Pros:+ Very few games lead to more shouts of "just one more!"+ Hones and rewards your ability to read your friends+ Proper observation requires lots of eye contact+ Hilarious banter guaranteed making it a perfect party game+ A rare social bluffing game that works with less than 5 players+ Easy to learn and accessible for all ages+ Great bang for your buckCons:- Won't be much fun if you're opposed to ever bluffing- Randomness is obviously a big part of the game- The endgame is often quite predictable

I love this game. After seeing it at a gaming program at my library I immediately ordered the game for myself and downloaded the iOS app version for my iPhone. This bluffing game is fast to play and a lot of fun right out of the box.The instructions are comprehensive and clear although it's easier to make sense of the game by playing a few practice rounds. Everything you need for game play is in the box and there are options to buy expansions as well to make the game work for even more players.I am very happy with the versatility of this game and with how deceptively simple it is. Coup is one of those games that takes minutes to learn and a lifetime to master.

Game is very fun to play, although I suggest watching videos of other people playing first just so you can get a feel for how the game goes before you buy the game. I watched Achievement Hunter play this game on YouTube which was what originally made me want to purchase this game in the first place. I think you could learn this game without watching someone else play although for me, having that knowledge already makes it a lot easier and fun to introduce to people who haven't played it before. Once everybody knows how to play you'll want to pull this game out again and again.
