This game is so much fun! A little difficult to explain to a group of players but after a practice round, everything was clear. If I had to do anything differently, I would buy the 12 Player version so that we could have a larger group. The more people, the more fun! A huge hit at Christmas Eve! Youngest player was 9 years old and the oldest was 53.

This is one of the best games we have played. Haven't laughed so much in years.  Our Friday nite game group tried this. It was an instant hit.  We play with 6-8 players.  We did find it wasn't as much fun with 4or less players and we could easily adjust game for more.  Recommended it to friends across US and they have loved it as well.  Should be game of the year.  8and up and mixed age DoubleClick all play.  They also have a large party version some friend bought and love.

This is a great game for a bunch of friends just wanting to sit back and be silly. If you've never played it, it's a graphical take on the old "telephone" game where you whisper a phrase to the person next to you and they pass it down the line, then you compare what the first person said to what the last person heard. In this case, you're drawing the word or phrase and the next person has to guess and then the next person has to draw what they guessed, so on down the line. The results can be absolutely hilarious. The dry erase markers are a bit cheap but it's not hard to find replacement markers at the local drug store. Also, one of my books was put together in the wrong order which made it confusing the first time we played it. But since they are spiral bound, we just took it apart and put the pages in the correct order. It wasn't something that affected our enjoyment of the game.

review_title: Great family game!  Everyone loves it.
review_description: This is such a wonderful game for family game night we've played with kids as young as 7 and adults as old as 75.  Easy to learn, but we changed the rules a bit- we allow players to chose any phrase or word on their chosen card to illustrate.  We also never keep score- It's so much fun to walk through the various illustrations and laugh, by the time we've shared everyone's, no one cares what a score might be.  (Eliminates so much bickering as well!) EIther way you play this game is a hit.

review_title: This game is a blast for all ages!
review_description: Recommended to me. I ordered it with fingers crossed; Game Day was two days away! It arrived as everyone arrived. We ditched all the other games we had planned and all of us, ages from 59 to 7 played this game exclusively for 5-6 hours! We usually have a card game, board game, puzzle and kids' game going. This was FUN!

review_title: Fun and easy to play with all ages.
review_description: I originally played the game with my sons family over the holidays.  They received it as a gift.  We played with ages between 72 and 7 years.  Other than being lenient with the timer, with the younger ones involved, we found it easy to play and a lot of fun for all of us.  I bought one as a gift shortly after I played and now bought one for my own household for when we have family or company over.  It is a good icebreaker and does not take a lot of talent to do the drawings.

review_title: Hilarious game for the whole family!
review_description: The rules are simple so it's easy to get playing right away. The first time we played with 8 people aged 10 to 66 and we laughed so hard our faces ached after. We played again with a group of 8 aged 5 to 45 and it was a bit tough for the 5 year old but everyone still had a blast. I absolutely love the game. We tried it with a group of 4 tonight and laughed to tears. We only used the timer one round and I don't think it's necessary unless you have someone you're always needing to wait for. Wonderful concept, easy and super fun to play.To play, each person has a little spiral book with whiteboard like pages. Everyone draws one card that has a word like "castle" or a simple concept.  With an even number of players, each person draws their word and passes it to the next person who then writes their guess of what the picture represents, and that continues until it gets back to the original owner.What makes this game extra special to me is everyone does something every round. You get to actively participate the whole time. Also awful drawers aren't really a drawback because their awful attempts add a whole new level of hilarity. We found this a great family game and look forward to playing again!Wishes: I wish I'd gotten the party pack so I had 12 pads. I'd like more cards. I felt like we repeated them too quickly. I'd happily buy card or pad expansions.

review_title: This game is proof board games are not dead!
review_description: If you are looking for a huge amount of laughter and fun with your friends and family.......this is the game! I was introduced to this game by friends and our mouths hurt from laughing and smiling so much. What a great concept executed nicely in this board game. After buying it my family and I have lured several friends over with offers of dinner and a “board game”. They have all arrived hungry but not real jazzed about a board game. They have all walked out of here exclaiming this is the most fun they’ve had in quite some time! There are two versions. The other one is the ADULT version and comes in a black box. My review is for the family version. Read the description carefully and make sure you are getting the correct one. Have a blast!

We played this game - for the first time - for my daughter's 30th surprise birthday party!  There were 3 generations of us and we all had a ball!Pros:Fun, fun and funSuper simple to learnLove the wipe-off bookletsYou don't have to be an artist to playCons:One marker barely workedGame should include extra markers because if they don't work - you can't playIf you want to return this game for some reason - which you won't - you have to pay about $8 to ship it back!

review_title: A great twist on Pictionary and the Telephone game
review_description: A great twist on Pictionary and the Telephone game.  My artistic ability is nil but it's still fun to see what others draw and guess.  The markers are very cheap.  Two of the markers were dried out when we opened the box for the first time.  The tips of the markers are very thick for the small size of the drawing books.  We use small dry erase markers we have around the house.  The booklets get "stained" easily, too.  After each time we play, we take wet paper towels and clean the pages.  Do not use windex because it will ruin the pages!  My friend did that with her game and now one of her pages she has paper taped to it and they just change out the paper each round.  The little eraser cloths get filled up quickly and it's hard to erase everything on the page.

review_title: Extremely fun party game that's all about having fun and not really about scoring points or winning
review_description: After my friends introduced me to this game, I just had to get it. Every time I've played it, it has really not been about winning or scoring points (although you could easily do that). As a matter of fact, the worse people draw and/or guess, the more fun this game becomes. It really does become a challenge to see if your word can make it all the way around.It's a great party game and for that reason I would recommend you get an 8 player version or higher. The more people, the more fun the game.The game itself is well designed and arrived in good shape. The only negative for me was that it came with 7 good dry-erase markers and 1 that was missing a cap and was dried out. The cap was not in the box either so it must have been a manufacturing mistake. I did not return the game or complain about this because I have plenty of dry erase markers at home.

review_title: Great game but markers don't work
review_description: We bought this game to bring on vacation.  We played a few times with 7 adults and found it to be great fun.  Unfortunately, the dry erase markers that came with the game do not work well.  The game comes with 8 markers.Two didn't work from the beginning, and one stopped working soon after.  This put a damper on our fun, as sharing markers really delays the game.  I would suggest that if you buy this game, consider buying a multipack of black dry erase markers at the same time, which will, unfortunately, increase the cost of the game.  So, while the game is fun, it ends up being more expensive than it seems.  It's too bad the manufacturer hasn't supplied a reliable product.

review_title: This was awesome and we're a tough crowd
review_description: A group of us have an ongoing game night.  We are mixed bag of all ages and backgrounds.  Naturally,  we started with everyone's favorite, cards against humanity, which we enjoyed but we like trying new games.  It seems that so many are just slight twists on Cards Against Humanity.  I read the reviews on this and decided to give it a shot so I had to share that we ALL just loved it.  I would bring this home to play with my parents and kids.  All ages.... and really simple as far as learning but so fun.  Give it a shot.  You'll like it!!!  Fun fun fun.  Ali in Raleigh

We played this game over Christmas at relatives and had so much fun that I wanted the game for our family for game night with friends.  Imagine my surprise when I opened my Amazon box and it was the ADULT version!!  (Yikes!)  (the reason for only 4 stars)  Amazon was very good about returning the wrong version and replacing it with the correct FAMILY friendly version and all is good!  If you are wanting a game that will have you laughing until you can't breath and your stomach hurts - this is the game!  It is a little pricey but I think you'll get your money worth.

review_title: Very fun for all ages, the more players the better
review_description: Our family loves this, for all ages, even if you can't draw (even better if you can't, as it's more fun that way!).  The 8 player version came with pens that the tops didn't fit on the ends of the pens, that was not good, so we bought some different DRY ERASE pens that were better.  We also have the 12 player version and those pens were right.  You will want to get some dry erase cleaner to clean the cards after playing a few times - as you use a cloth to erase after each round, and like all dry erase things they don't come completely clean (until you use a cleaner).  The cloth cleaners that come with the game are too small for serious players too – so get some better erasers at school or office supply store and you will enjoy the game more.So what are you paying for? Cards to write on, and a deck of cards that will give you works to draw, a board, dice, etc., and a lot of fun – trust me, it’s worth it (shop the sales, online, and you can get this game for a good deal)

review_title: So fun for the whole family!
review_description: I play this with my daughter and 2 grandchildren and we all love it.  We don't bother keeping score because we're having too much fun to care.  And forget about the 12+ age suggestion.  My granddaughter is 7-1/2 and my grandson is almost 11.  Some of words/phrases are beyond the kids, so we just let them pick any selection on the card, whereas the rules say to throw the dice and pick the choice that corresponds to that number.  You can save that rule for the 12+ group.

review_title: Put away the phones and pull out Telestrations
review_description: What can be said that already hasn't.  A very simple game in theory, you draw a picture on a small whiteboard, pass that picture to a neighbor who guesses what the picture is and passes the answer to the next neighbor who draws the answer provided.  So if the person started by drawing a violin and it goes through a series of drawings and guesses you hope the last drawing is a violin, but it will probably be a rocket ship or a giraffe or something.  No real points or winner in this game, more of a social game to get a group of people talking and having fun.  Great for parties and families.  My family loves playing this game together.

review_title: Such a fun game - for the whole family!
review_description: Love this game! Loved it so much, we bought the larger size (12). Great for all ages, but I will say that sometimes the cards are a little difficult for smaller children to guess and draw. So we prefer to play an adults game and kids game separately. Provides a ton of laughter. The end results sometimes brings us all to tears. Highly recommend for your next night in for Family Game Night.

The classic Elementary school game, Telephone, meets Pictionary and SO much fun ensues. The game is easy enough for any sized group and it is so much fun to go back on the cards and see where things went awry. It's not appropriate for children just because some of the cards you draw are a bit more advanced and sometimes more adult, but I'm sure that kids could play if a parent filtered through the draw cards first. Definitely a must have for game night!

review_title: Folks from 5 to 105 will love this!
review_description: Just as the reviews we read said!  Brings out the craziness of even the stiffest holiday guest!  All ages over 5 (unless you have a little Einstein in your midst) seemed to have the same connection to the game.  It was a little confusing to sort out at first, and we all read and reread the directions a second time with the equipment all distributed in front of us to help catch on to the rules easier.  We all thought it would have been a little easier to use if the markers were not quite so fat and a lot thinner at their tips.  This would also create a much smaller mess to clean up after each game.  This is a wonderful game to allow children and adults to play together and be equally fulfilled and happy.

review_title: Played this at a friend's house and HAD to own it
review_description: This game is great.  It's quick to play a round and people can drop in or leave in between rounds without issue so it makes a great mixer game.  It's great that the worse  you (and/or your guests) are at drawing, the more fun you'll have.  Other games are too dependent on scoring points as a result of passable artistic skills.  This is more like "Who's line is it anyway" (can I reference that on Amazon?) where the points don't matter.  It can, in fact, be more fun to lose spectacularly.

I have found this obviously works best with a minimum of 5 and the more the merrier.  Kids as young as 7 can pick it up but spelling out their guess is the hardest part for them.  Over time new dry erase markers will be needed. We modified the rules to not keeping score but to just do round after round till everyone gets a turn to pick a word.  Crazy how a small word such as cat turn into some weird creation like a chimera. Lol. Enjoy!!

review_title: The game is really fun! We played it with a bunch of adults ...
review_description: The game is really fun! We played it with a bunch of adults and had a blast. Then played with our family of four. Not as much fun as with eight players (it goes really fast). I then played it with a friend and our combine five daughters who are grades 5 through High School and it was fun. We bent the rules a little and let the girls pick any word off of the list rather than rolling the dice and making them draw the corresponding number. The kids loved it!Super bummed that only 2 of the 8 pens worked!! We had to share pens the first time we played (which sucks the fun out) and then I bought wipe board markers for the next game.

review_title: What's up with the dried-up markers?!
review_description: We love this game and decided to buy the 8-player version for our Granddaughter. TWO of the brand-new markers were dried up. How in the heck does that happen???? Can Customer Service please forward a few extra markers so that we can replace the defective ones - nothing worse than having a granddaughter somewhat disappointed with a Christmas gift.:(

Purchased this for a slumber party for a group of 8-9 year olds. The came was more complicated than it needed to be. We tried a couple rounds and then scrapped the whole thing for good old pictionary on a white board.  This might be fun with an older group, but I think the team aspect of these games (when you have a group) is often what makes them fun, and you lose that with this game.

review_title: It wound up working even better than I expected
review_description: I got this game specifically as an icebreaker for a new work team meeting for the first time.  It wound up working even better than I expected!  I only intended it to be used for one 20-minute session but everyone had SO much fun with it, we did another session immediately and shorted up actual work time to accommodate it, lol.  Then the team asked me to bring it along to our work dinner that night, so we played it yet one more time in the restaurant.

review_title: This has to be one of my favorite games to date
review_description: This has to be one of my favorite games to date.  We played with family a few nights ago, and before the night was over I had already ordered from Amazon so I would have my own copy of the game.  Think TELEPHONE and how quickly things can get off base when passing a whisper from person to person, and then add the fact that its not a whisper, but a guess on a drawing or a rendition of the previous person's guess.  When you get all the way around you have 4 drawings and 4 guesses of what your drawing and word was, and it can be darn funny.  We laughed until we cried many many times the night we played.I highly recommend this game!

The game concept is simple: Write down a word or phrase. Draw that word or phrase. Pass the drawing to the next player, who writes down a guess. Pass that guess to the next person, who draws THAT word or phrase. Repeat four times. You score points for the best drawing, the best guess, and if the correct word or phrase survives four rounds (eight players) worth of "telephone." This game came highly recommended, and I picked it up for Thanksgiving with the family. We laughed until we cried. Absolutely hilarious! Some of the phrases on the cards just beg for a disaster, and others are categories, blanks (make up your own starting word!), and the like. I cannot recommend this game highly enough, not only because it's good for all ages and easy to play, but because it self-adjusts to the crowd. Lots of little kids? Lots of stick figures and cute times. Lots of adults drinking around the table? Lots of really, really hilarious and (if your family is like mine) borderline-inappropriate cartoons. All in all, a wonderful product, well-packaged and well-executed. Everything is dry-erase, so set-up and tear-down is a snap. More copies of this are being purchased as we speak, and we will definitely be providing it as a gift for a few people this holiday season. Five stars across the board for hilarious family fun.

review_title: Some fundamental changes in this version
review_description: Some fundamental changes in this version that I don’t like. They added an Event deck in an effort to mix things up which I appreciate in theory but every card in it is a “take that” card that makes you take money from other players.  This is a big change from the earlier versions of the game where you played against the game and your budget with no real “take that”.  For playing with younger players that allows for a semi-cooperative experience and is much less aggressive than this new version. They also did away with Savings accounts and its interest and only have Loans now which I didn’t care for as not having that removes a good opportunity to teach kids about saving vs spending in their budget. I returned this version and am keeping my older copy.  It’s a good attempt at refreshing the game but is not for me.

Awesome game to help kids/teens learn about finances and unexpected costs. Also shows them ways to make money. Simple to play for young children 7 ish plus, but has enough details to keep up with a teen.Every child should play this game to get familiar with how to handle money properly. It's not an end all be all cure to teach children about money, but is a great tool to teach them financial strategies. :)Personal Experience:My 7 and 8 year old love the game and beg to play. My 5 year old plays and we help him along. He likes it too.My 7 and 8 year old could easily be banker. The first time we played the 7 and 8 year old ended up broke and both cried. We paused the game, and explained that this is how some people live...they just don't have enough money to pay all their bills. We (my husband and I) said to them that money and bills are not as easy as we (mom and dad) make it look in real life. We advised them to look for money making opportunities and play it out to the end. They did, and now both enjoy the game now that they know how to be more responsible with money.My 7 and 8 year old have even brought up about spending money in real life situations now. That makes me feel like I did something right.This game was a really good investment.

Ok, so when I was a kid I remember playing Payday. So when my kids decided that we needed to add Payday to the pile I was ok with that. The game arrived quickly and was good... it just wasn't the game I remembered. The cute little quirky mail cards used to include little postcards and fun things - but in this version those cute little quirky things are replaced with markup cards that are really no good for anything until you sell an item. They are really minor complaints, and the kids don't care. But if you are a fan of the old game this one might be a bit of a let down.

I credit this board game for teaching me about money management. It was my favorite game when I was young and I couldn't wait to teach my kids how to play. They are 8 & 6 and picked it up quickly. They lost interest in Yahtzee after a few rounds so I wasn't too optimistic this would be any different. I was pleasantly surprised at how much this game kept their attention. We went two months the first time and they immediately wanted to play again. We ended up playing for five hours that night! I loved listening to them complain about having to pay for haircuts and oil changes... 😁

review_title: Lots of rules, pieces etc know before you buy
review_description: Not for my family- to many complicated rules.  We kept it and changed the rules.  It has more rules than Monopoly.  If your ok with a more complicated game this is for you.  Lots of parts/pieces.  We play Life instead.

The description on the box made me believe the game would be fun and fast pace. There were so many rules and it was so complicated and boring that we just closed the box back up. I would not recommend this game for family night with kids but more so for analytical thinkers or people with more patience.

Wanted to get this for my family as I had it when I was little. This game has changed A LOT since I played it back in the 90's. It gets some getting used to, but overall its a good game. Not recommended for little ones under 6. Package came on time with no issues or damage.

review_title: Blast from the past Payday game
review_description: Remember this game from my childhood so I ordered it to play with my family during the quarantine. It was a blast. We all had fun. Definitely for older kids. Received the game quickly and was in perfectly new condition. Very pleased. Recommend seller.
Like the old one better.
We enjoy this game. The auction aspect is a bit odd to me. I wish we could get the original version instead, but this is a good filler for something different.
I just love this game. I played it as a kid all the time and felt the real stressors of making it through the month without enough money. #reallife Thank goodness for the lottery section of the game.
My sister and I played this as kids and decided to introduce it to our kids on game night. It was a hit! We have kids ages 12 to 26 and they all thought it was fun. PS- the 12 yr old won.

I didn’t realize that the payday game had been “moderenized”. I didn’t like it as much as the old game. It’s seem unnecessarily more complicated. They added an auction part to the game where you can “screw over” other players which I didn’t really like. We ended up going back and buying the old pay day. Much simpler.

This game is awesome introduction to life as a preteen. A child learns a lot from this game, everything from buying and selling to budgeting to the end of the month when bills are due..Recommend to parents who think it’s important for their child to learn to manage their money. Fast delivery..
I am giving this as a gift, quick shipping

My family and I love it. We play it all the time. It helps kids see real things about life, it teaches them it’s not all about fun that their is still bills to pay! There is serval twists and we love it! We have played it for 5 days straight!! I Recommend it to anyone!
We had fun playing. Never played it before so took a while to figure out.
Fun family game.  Helps kids learn life lessons about money in a fun way.
Great game for family
Not the Classic Game!
Kids absolutely love this game! Lots of fun and fast shipping!
Fun game!
We are still trying to figure out how to play this game. I think it would be more fun if we could figure it out. Seems like it would be more fun if you had 4 players over 2
Fun...reasonable price
Like the modern look
Christmas gift
My children and I spent many hours playing Payday when they were small.  Whichever was being the banker wouldquickly make change.  This taught them to make change without a calculature.
Fun classic game, entertaining for variety of ages.
This was purchased door a Christmas gift so has not been opened.
My grand-daughter and I did not like this game. She said that she liked the one when we played it years ago
This is such a fun family game!  Even my 13 year old likes it!
Grand son loves it
Fast shipping! Played to night and remembered how much I hate that game lmao ty

Played this at a friends house and had to have it. We haven't bought a new game in a while and were getting tired of our old ones. This one makes up for it. It is fun and interactive. Highly recommend.

review_title: It was a gift for my granddaughter! So, ...
review_description: It was a gift for my granddaughter! So, I know she loves her it because she asked for it.,lol
As described
If you want a quick, fun game .. buy this!  Every home needs this one for game night.
It was a gift and he loved it
Bought this for my nephew and he loves it.  He’s 11.
Great game from my youth
Perfect for gift
It is a great past-time for the family and provides a light introduction to budget management for kids.
Kids love this game
The whole family love this game.
It arrived super fast and undamaged. Super excited to play this later.
This is a fun game that the family enjoys. However, this appeared to be the original, but it is not the same
Super fun my kids love this game!
Grandkids love the game

review_title: Good game. Not that worth it
review_description: Amazing game. A bit overpriced for what it actually is
Product was as described.  Great game!

Played this with my mom tonight. I had watched a video of how to play beforehand, and I have played the video game so I had a pretty good idea of how it would go. Still, I thought it would be a lot harder to explain to my mom who hasn't had any experience with the game or area control games than it turned out to be. We had no problems figuring out how to play, the game loop is very fun, well written rules and the few problems we did have were easily found right away in the rules. The artwork is exactly what you would expect, functional and does the job just like the video game. High quality parts and some nice little details like the "death" dice has little red blood splatters on it. We both had so much fun and I can't wait to play it again with more people! I have a feeling this is going to end up as a top favorite for me on game nights. :) 10/10

LOVE this game!  My husband and I play the ipad version so we were curious to find out they had a board game.  We have played the board game now quite a few time with just us two and a few times with friends, once you learn the rules the game is a blast!  Our first game took about 3 hours, while we read the instructions and figured out what was what, but after the first game we were able to play each additional game within 1 hour and 30 minutes.  It is so much fun!

review_title: Forced family fun gives this a TEN!
review_description: My husband is always looking for fun family games...this is definitely on the top of our list as we had the app on our phones and when we heard about the game....had to get it!  Even my 2nd child who's always escaping "forced family fun" LOVED this game!

review_title: Fun strategy game that's not excessively complicated.
review_description: This game is really fun!  It involves a lot of strategy but is not needlessly complicated; once you get the rules down it goes smoothly. It is just as fun with two people as it is four. Haven't tried it alone yet but you can play it that way too! Bought it for my boyfriend as a Christmas present and he has thanked me for it about ten times.

review_title: An infectious addition to game night.
review_description: Just played session 1, 3 players. Took about an hour. None of us knew how to play but it took us 1 turn to get it, set it up, follow the instructions step by step once and you are good.The game is awesome! You get to steal countries from other players, very cut throat, the simple play makes it go fast that I didnt even notice the play time as it went by. The companion app is nice too, with a leader board for those competitive types (ME!), The ambient music is just the video game sound track, there is a die roller, which is rather pointless. And lastly a random disease name generator! That is truly fun!

Our family loves playing board games. I bought this to take to my sister's house and we played a round. The directions are a little bit hard to follow, but we figured it out by playing the game step by step with the instructions and then played a round without them. It was just as fun as the video game! We all loved it. You definitely need more than 2 people though to play or else it really doesn't last long. We will be bringing this to all the family gatherings for sure!
Get it now..... I thought that the instructions did not make any sense when bought but then i watched the tutorial vid on Youtube and that really helped me/...

Great fun.The bored is very well designed. There is no better feeling than competing with friends to see who can kill the human race the fastes.only down side for me is the player prices I wish for one set the would have not used red. That set blends in with the bored to much. An wish there was more diseases

The pieces are translucent & colorful. Very satisfying to look at. The art for the board & cards is very nice as well. I like that the Confusion card has an effect of something like cold resistance & air transmission, with the description being "We have no idea why confusion gives you cold resistance & air transmission."

review_title: Great game, easy to learn and fun to play
review_description: It may not be as fun during the current CORVID19 outbreak, but in general - it's fun. The quality is good, the rules are clear and simple. Can be played for up to 4 players, or singleplayer (which is very unusual for the board games). I played this game on PC and spent good time. The board adaptation is as good as the PC original. They are very different, though.

Great game.  Definitely need to download the companion app.  It gives detailed videos on game setup and instructions.  Took us a minute to get everything right but we enjoyed playing.  Definitely for older children and adults.

review_title: Great board game based of the videogame!
review_description: Fun game with quite some strategy involved, took us a couple plays to fully understand it but we had a blast once we got it.Now its one of our favorites.I love that it also comes with a single player mode.
Love love love this game! It took awhile to learn it and my fiance and I had to YouTube the game play but once we learned we couldn't stop playing. We even taught a few friends pretty simply.

This is a really fun game unlike Pandemic the players play against each other. It's nice to work with everyone in curing a disease, but sometimes it's more fun to win by eliminating everyone else. In fact, once one player can't play anymore the game stops. If you see you have and advantage and can knock out a player earlier then you can do that. There are a lot of different ways and variations in playing Plague. The material is solidly built and should last a long time.

I enjoyed the phone version of this game! So, when I saw it was available as a board game, I had to try it. Everyone that we've had over to play has enjoyed it. There is a minimal learning curve, and once you have the game mechanics down, it has a ton of replayability. We enjoyed it so much we bought the expansion!
Kids love it (9, 10, 13). Lots of rules that seem complicated but you pick it up very quickly. Games does take a while to play but you can adjust minor things to speed up.

not a family game or a game for kids. it's just too confusing to learn the rules and try to figure out how to play. it's awesome though as a solo game, but at that point you pay as well download the app and spend the money on unlocking the levels and such early. save you tons of time.

review_title: One of the Best Board Games Ever!
review_description: I really enjoyed playing this game with my brothers. This is a game of strategy and luck. It isn't too hard to learn, and the playing experience is amazing! I love the video game, and I was skeptical at first how this video-game-turned-board-game would turn out, but they did an awesome job at creating this! Will play it over and over again! I will eventually buy the expansion pack so I can play with all of my brothers in one game (five people total with expansion).

review_title: Fun game to play alone or with friends
review_description: Being a huge fan of the android version,  I had to have this.  As far as table games go, it's pretty easy to learn after a few play throughs.  It's challenging,  fun,  exciting,  and versatile with a few different ways to play (including solo).

My 7 year old  grandson ask for this game.  I couldn't figure it out and gave to my 35 year old daughter to try, she couldn't figure it out so it is now with her husband to try.  I do not recommend to regular families.

Not the best timing on this purchase.  It is a fun game, although not as fun or flexible as the video game counterpart.  Not always a balanced game, if you get too far ahead there isn't much chance of your opponent catching up.
Well, this turned out to be a particularly salient purchase. :|

Husband loves the app game so I had to get him this. It’s his new fave board game and he tries to get everyone to play with him. It is tons of fun. And finally we have a game that is fun to play with just two people so we can have a fun night when it’s just the two of us.

I got this for my son for his birthday and he loves it. He's only seven so he needs some guidance but luckily my husband (who plays a *lot* of games) loves it too. According to him it's one of the best games he's played in a long time: well thought out, strategic, balanced, and lots of fun. Well worth the pricetag.

My 11-year-old son is a HUGE fan of Plague Inc. online and couldn't wait for this game to be released.  This game quickly became one of my favorites.  It's been a HUGE hit all summer while camping! Great for kids and adults!  EXCELLENT!!!

This game is much, much more casual than most table top games me and my crew play. But oddly, we still very much enjoy it. This game is definitely geared toward families,  it very easy to understand and play. But I still recommend it for for serious groups, as there is many different play styles, options, and outcomes.
Seriously fun. I recommend playing this game with family or friends. It legit is a fun game. If you can get the expansion you should. It adds to the fun. Personally my favorite board game.
Love this game. It's easy to play for the whole family ages 8 and up. Only downside is my family has stopped playing it with me because I always win!
More than a game to learn in an hour. It has many good qualities that my grandchild wanted it but too much for me to enjoy. This is a strategy game.

Gifted this to the family for Christmas. We play pandemic quite a bit and felt like being the bad guys for once! I’ve played the flash game and mobile game and we all enjoyed this board game. Everything was quality and the colors are great. Gameplay is really fun - I think it will be played many times. Instructions are pretty good and videos are even better. Easy to play.
Very fun to play. 2-4 player constrain makes it possible to play it between a couple. Need some time to learn. But once you had played it one time it will go smoothly.

I played with 3 other people, I’d say the first time playing, the instructions are 100% clear. I say disregard the “rule book” and just read the simplified instructions on the individual player boards. It’s really simple, easy, and fun, once you get going. I can’t wait to play again

review_title: Worth taking the time to learn how to play!
review_description: Super fun game! There is a learning curve but it is worth learning for sure. Strategy is a sizeable part of the game.
We really enjoy this game a lot. It’s one of our “go to” games. Fun, easy to learn. I laminated the place cards for durability.

This game is awesome. I have played a lot of the mobile game and I didn't know how it would translate onto a board game platform. But to my surprise, the game holds very true to the mobile game but unique in its own way.

review_title: The game is great, I just wished it came with the expansion
review_description: The gameplay is great and it has beautifully detailed pieces and cards. The game modes are competitive and I like the single-player option which gives the game more ways to play it. I just wished it came with the expansion included since it sometimes feels like the game is lacking gameplay
Easy to set up and play, even tho one player will get himself killed fairly soon if he really doesn't feel like playing.  We just let him die and continue with the rest of us.
We really enjoyed our first play through tonight. The learning process is lengthy but easy. Can’t wait to play again!
Once you figure out how to play it, this game is great. Fun for ages 10 and up. You’ve got to have patience. My younger one got tired of waiting for his turn.

My 13 year old asked for this for Christmas. It was starred on list, meaning it was important. I bought it, we played. It was a lot better than I expected. Lots of strategy involved. It is a really cool unique game allowing for thinking to go on in order to win. Lots of different outcomes based on how you play it. I recommend.

review_title: Great game for family and students
review_description: It’s slow to start, when you’re introducing the game to new players. But once they get the hang of the rules, it can be fun and interesting.I use it as a reward game for my high school students during the last week of the year, and they enjoy it.

Great game. I've played it a half a dozen time since getting it an have enjoyed every game. It has similar thinking to Risk, but without quite as much direct adversarial conflict. If you are looking for an everyone vs everyone game where the board won't get flipped over in frustration, this hits the sweet spot.

If you are familiar with the game for phones then you will enjoy this. its 2-4 players and really easy to jump into it.  My friend and I actually mix it up playing with bacteria vs virus and so on.  Great game if you want to destroy humanity!

review_title: Excellent board game adaptation from a fun mobile game
review_description: Excellent board game adaptation from a fun mobile game.  My daughter and I love it!  We've played it multiple times with her friends since getting it for Christmas.  Definitely a good purchase!

review_title: Enough difference from the video game to keep you interested
review_description: Very fun with high replay value.High quality pieces and high definition pictures. We’ve played 3 times now and can see that it’ll be fun for a long time to come.

review_title: One of the only games that is still fun with 2 players
review_description: Directions were a little confusing, but I watched the video's and picked it up in 15 minutes! One of the only games that is still fun with 2 players.
It's a great game that takes about an hour to an hour and a half to finish. I does take a little time to learn but when you do learn how to play it, it is really fun.
Great game. Played the phone version  and love it. Board game is just as fun.
This game is so much fun. My family has been playing the app version on our phones for years. It was so much fun adding a new spin to the game!
My sons love this sickening game.

I had played the classic version years ago, but with young kids complicated board games are a little off the table for now. This version was great for me and my big two (6 years and 8 years). They picked it up quickly - the 8 year old won the first game even against both parents. There's still enough strategy to make it interesting but the winner is mostly the one who draws the right cards at the right time.I know some young kids are ready for the full version early, (and great for them!) but for our household with 4 young kids, we just don't have the time and focus to devote to a long and complicated game. 20 minutes and simple gameplay is about all we can handle before the toddlers tear the house apart.I would say if the YOUNGEST in the house is focused and able to handle longer games, just get the classic version and adapt for them. But in our situation this one is the winner for the next few years.

review_title: Nice "simple" version for very young children
review_description: This was just the "beginner's game" to get my 9-year-old hooked.  Once she learned the basics with this game, she "graduated" quickly to the "regular" series, and now she loves the whole series.Nice "simple" version for very young children; recommended.

We have the regular version of TTR and my 6 year old son has always taken an interest in it but it was a bit difficult for him to keep up with and also too long.  This version has been perfect, he doesn't need help and likes to get it out all the time.

My 6 year old absolutely loves this game!  It took her a couple rounds to figure out the rules and now she's an expert.  It's easy enough to setup, too, to where she get it ready before it's time to play (or forces me to play LOL).Since it does require some reading and following directions, my 4 year old can't play on his own.  But he can put the trains down on the board which is fine by him.I haven't played the full size game myself, but I have a feeling she'll be ready to play soon.

Ticket to ride is one of our favorites!  They did an excellent job simplifying it without dumbing it down too much. Children are still required to make a strategic plan, keeping it entertaining for the whole family. My only beef is that Washington DC is labeled Washington. Being from the pacific north west, my children find this confusing. We did have to watch a YouTube video when we learned how to play the adult version. It’s easy once you get it, but the directions can feel overwhelming.

with a family that includes kids.  It took us a while to figure out the instructions, and the 6 year old needed help playing.  The rest of us, including adults, had a bit of difficulty too.  All routes got blocked so no one could win.  Maybe the adult version, which has more routes, would be easier, since the destinations would be harder to block.  Being sent to Goodwill.

review_title: This version is perfect for him and still keeps us entertained
review_description: Our entire family enjoys playing this game. We have played the adult version for years and our 7 year old always wants to join in. This version is perfect for him and still keeps us entertained. It took him a couple rounds to really get the concept and rules down. Game play for 4 takes about 45 minutes. Great game to play on weeknights after dinner!

review_title: Greatly simplified version of the original game. My 5-year-old ...
review_description: Greatly simplified version of the original game. My 5-year-old daughter loves this though we play with an open hand until she gets the hang of all the strategy.

review_title: 5 year old LOVES it, as do mom and dad
review_description: My wife and I started playing full Ticket to Ride years ago on XBox and the iPad.  I've been excited to get this for my oldest son since I first saw it.  Does not disappoint!Simplifies the game greatly (i.e. no points on ticket cards), and my 5 year old is already learning some beginners geography and strategy.  It's still advanced enough that my wife and I genuinely love playing it (especially compared to boring Candyland, Chutes and Ladders, etc...).I'd even recommend this over the full version for most people.  While we haven't played the full Ticket to Ride besides using XBox/iPad, I can imagine the process of keeping score without the assistance of the computer would be annoying.  This doesn't have any points concept at all, likely making it a much more laid back experience.

Let me start out by saying that we are huge fans of the original Ticket to Ride. My husband and I play all the time but our 6 year old wasn't quite ready. I had been going back and forth on the kid version for a while but decided to try it. I am so glad we did. It is so much fun! It is the same idea as the original but the game play is much easier to accommodate the kids. We play with our oldest often and us parents are having just as much fun. For newbies to Ticket to Ride, it's a game where you collect train routes and the first person to complete 6 routes wins. It is a blast! This game is a great intro to strategy without being overly competitive or confusing. I highly recommend to kids even as young as 5.

This game is excellent.  Where to begin.Just picking up the box you can tell the quality.  It is HEAVY!  The components in this game are great.  The construction of the board is one of the best I have ever seen.  It is thick, has sturdy folds, large (easy for people to crowd around), and has some nice visuals which are important for children to use if they cannot read yet so trying to complete a ticket is able to be done by a younger child.  The plastic train pieces are detailed, and the game comes with extras just in case (with kids you are bound to lose some.....possibly even to them playing with the nice pieces outside of using them for the game because they are that nice) and each color comes with its own zip-lock baggie.  The card are thick, appealing, and high quality with a nice sheen, and the organizer in the box fits everything perfectly.The game play is simple yet competitive, where you need to strategize and possibly try to block your opponents ability to create a route to complete tickets (the objective of the game) if you can figure out their goals.  This game can be played on so many levels, even as a quick game with adults (if you want to have more competition, you can play with a modified rule set which is awesome.  You can basically use the "express" version rules to increase difficulty so the game can grow with the children's ability to provide years of entertainment!)  Younger children can even play it and be competitive against adults as well because the game has an intuitive rule set.This game is a win on so many different levels that I wish other games were made and designed as well as this.

review_title: Fun for kids, directions are a bit complicated
review_description: I bought this for my 8 year old nephew.  He has been playing it with his 6 year old brother and his parents.  The directions were not that easy for them to follow, and they have made up their own directions to simplify it for the kids, so when I tried to play following the actual directions it was a bit complicated and led to some misunderstandings.Anyway, I am sure this is a fun game for kids, but maybe it could have simpler game play and directions, especially if the age range is 6 plus.

Taught it to kids from kindergarten to entering 6th grade. They all enjoyed it and the kindergartener was even able to make decisions an play with minimal support. It is a good intro to the Original game.  Done rules are different. No score keeping, routes have pictures to help young players.

This is a decent game for kids. My kid learned to play it at age four but has gotten better at understanding the rules and strategies now at five. However, like the original Ticket to Ride, it still involves having a lot of cards in hand, which can be hard for little ones. Also, the game is supposed to use pictures and words to help them keep track of their routes but the pictures on the cards don't always match the pictures on the gameboard. I think this is a overlook on part of the game designer. We buy a lot of games, and honestly this one doesn't hit the table as often as others.

review_title: Fun family game for young kids.
review_description: I bought this game as a gift for my son's 6th birthday and we have been playing ever since. This game has some flowes (instructions could be more detailed and all text is in one direction, so only one player faces it right, also names of towns can be obscured by trains, and there is nowhere on board to put cards so not every player can easily reach them) but in general it is fun and engaging. I think this game is suitable for children who at least can read alphabet letters and have patience and/or like board games. This one reminds me of Candy Lane, but in a much more advanced version.

review_title: She's got a ticket to ride... this fun game
review_description: Great game for young kids.Each city (on the map & destination tickets) has a unique image along with the city name so reading ability is not required. Kids just have to match the images on the cards with the images on the maps. My 5 and a half year old enjoyed it - we immediately played a second game right after the first. And my wife and I mildly enjoyed playing as well, which is more than you can ask for in a children's game.Game play really is similar to regular Ticket to Ride, just watered down. And it does play much faster, which is good.

review_title: Easy for kids, fun enough for adults.
review_description: I played this game with a 6 year old and a 4 year old. They loved it we played with our tickets showing and it was still fun. The 4 year old what’s to play it over and over again, and he won yesterday with no help. It’s very simple, but engaging enough that adults are willing to play it.

I love ticket to ride and my kids always watch the adults play and wish they could, but the adult version is too complex for them. When I saw this version was available I bought it and tried it with my kids and they loved it! It's a lot simpler but still has the fun concept of the game! My kids (9 and 7) were able to catch on really quickly and I love that it still requires them to strategize! If you're looking for a fun family game that keeps you and your littles entertained this is it!

I've played and really liked the original TTR, and had been looking at picking it up and playing with my daughter using modified rules for kids found on boardgamegeek.com.  In the end, I decided for the children's version for my just turned six year old.It's simpler and a smaller scale, but still very engaging.  My daughter quickly picked up on the game, using her wild cards well, using existing track to connect new routes, etc.  Bottom line is that she loves the game, and the box and board itself are much more appealing to a kid.  It's a sharp box.We really enjoy playing this, and has been fun to play even as an adult.  It's such an engaging and stimulating game, and I enjoy seeing my daughter's brain work and solve the puzzle of the routes.I can't recommend this game enough, especially if you already like the original TTR and want to introduce it to your young one.

review_title: U.S. Version, NOT Europe as Pictured
review_description: Excellent beginners game. My 4 year old was able to catch on right away and she has even won some games! After a few plays we are definitely ready to move on to the adult version of Ticket to Ride.Reasoning for my lower star rating is because we received the U.S. version but the stock photo on Amazon shows the European version. We really preferred the item as pictured, especially since the listing did not state we would receive something else.

review_title: Ticket to Ride is a winner
review_description: Our family likes playing games together and this is a new addition to our game library.  Both 9 year old and 6 year old boys love it and can play it easily.  I love how it involves strategy to choose your path wisely and to make it to as many destinations as possible before you run out of train cars.  On a side note, it also helps them with their US geography, but I don't tell them that part!

We bought this for my 5 year old son for Christmas and we have loved playing it together as a family. He always wanted to play Ticket to Ride with us but was too young to understand the strategy. With this simplified version he is able to play by himself and understand the basic concepts although he doesn’t understand all the strategy with this game either. I like that however since this game will grow with him over the years. Definitely recommend to families who love the original Ticket to Ride.

This game is really fun and challenging enough for adults to not be bored and kids to still enjoy. Compared to the regular ticket to ride game the board doesn't have as many lines so it is easier to look at. The cities are also designated by picture and text which is great for kids who are just learning to read and also makes it easier to identify on the board. Definitely one of my favorite games to play on game night.

We bought this for our 5 year old. He’s picking up on the game well. Only complaint is that there are only 22 trains in each color but the goal of the game is to complete 6 tickets which would require more trains. We usually finish around 4 tickets. Super fun and will create fans for the adult version!

I saw the reviews for the original and just had to get it for my 5 and 7 yo. My 5 yo doesn’t like to lose (who does?) so we had to hold back but after the 3rd time playing, he got it and was surpassing us!This takes a lot more strategy than the beginner childhood games that we play and they thrive on it. They feel so accomplished when finding round about pathways. I think they are ready for the original version but we are having so much fun with this one, we will just keep things the way they are...

review_title: Great into to Ticket to Ride
review_description: My wife and I have played Ticket to Ride for years and our 6 year old daughter was looking for new games to play.  This is a great introduction to the TtR world and she picked up on it right away.  The rules are easy to understand and doesn't have the complex points system of the adult game.I think this will be a new family favorite.

review_title: Perfect for an All Ages Game
review_description: My nieces are 6 years apart so it can be challenging to find a game that everyone can play and also be engaged and challenged at the same time. This really fits the bill. The almost 6 year old can play this (remarkably) well on her own and myself and the 11 year old still really enjoy it. There is some strategy involved but the element of chance really does level the playing field between all of us. So happy I picked this one up.

review_title: Fun game and a good B-day gift for hard to buy for kids.
review_description: Fun game to teach kids or give as a gift that most families won't already have. It is just a more simple version of full Ticket to Ride, but a bit easier for the kids to grasp. I am looking forward to my 7 year old playing the full version since she likes this version so much.

I bought this game for my mom to play with my eight year old son.She loves the adult version of the game, which is pretty expensive IMO for a board game, so this was a less expensive alternative.My son loves this game, so now both have a non-screen game to pass some time.

review_title: Buy this game for your family
review_description: This is a great game for parents and kids to play together. Our sons are 8,7&5 and they all loved the game. The first few times the 5 year old played partnered w a parent but now easily plays alone. We all enjoy the game. It’s fun for all ages and intellectually interesting even for adults. Excellent game for the family.

Easy to learn, easy to play. Lots of fun for young kids. The pieces are very light and easily shift on the board, getting knocked around by kids.But the overall game is very well designed, easy for young kids to learn and play.
This is one of our all time favorite games. Our 6 yr old granddaughter taught us how to play this game. 😊 We liked it so much we bought one to keep at our house for when the kids come over.

review_title: Playing every day with my 5 years old son
review_description: I am a big fan of full version of "Ticket To Ride" and was looking for a version for my 4.5 years old son.It took few times to understand rules for him (we skipped "Coast to Coast" rule at the very first time), but now we are playing every day. Definitely recommend it as a gift.

We've played the regular version of this game for years - it's one of our favorites. So, when we found this "Jr." version we were eager to try it. Our kids are 9 & 7 and we all enjoy playing it. I think it would even be fun for kids as young as 4 or 5!

Can I give this 10 stars? My daughter was giggling when she saw that she got a new game for her birthday. She is three years old. She wants to play this every night and is so good at it. Such a great game for all ages. I love playing this game with her.

This was recommended to us by a friend.  I enjoy it along with my 6 yr. old granddaughter.  It is easy enough but yet also has some strategy involved.  I plan on getting the regular version of the game as well in the future.

We bought this because our son wanted to play with us on the regular version, but had a hard time keeping up with so many cards and spaced on the routes.  This is an excellent alternative.  He is learning the basics and getting better at the "big people version" while loving this one.

review_title: Great learning and fun family game
review_description: My family loves this game.  We are a fan of this game.  Each ticket to ride if different.  This would be the best to start with with little ones. Kids constantly learn the routes and learn where cities are in the map.

Just finished playing for the first time with my 5, 7, and 8 year olds. They loved it! First time we ever played a game where sometime won and they all wanted to keep playing and were upset that it was over. Held the interest of my 5 yr old and still engaging enough for my oldest. Great game!

We love this game and play it every few days. We're upgrading to the adult version now as my 8 year old and I regularly tie. He's ready for more of a challenge but my 5 year old loves to play it. Great fun for the kids.

review_title: Great strategy game for young kids
review_description: This is such a fun game!  Both of my kids (6&8) love playing this game.  It is a great starter game for strategy games and we have played it many times since getting it.

Not sure why the hype. This game is OK. I find it visually confusing to look at the board with my trains and the routes all in the same mostly primary colors. Game feels slow and unexciting while you’re playing it. Overall, meh.
Really cool game. My bright 4 YO grand daughter loves playing this. (OK, what grand daughter isn't bright?)

review_title: MUST have for your game collection
review_description: My 5 year old loves this game! And my 3 year old loves playing on a team with me. This game is a must for your game collection. Everyone enjoys playing, kiddos and grown-ups! Get this game ASAP!

My son got this for his 5th Birthday. He would watch us play the other version but was excited that he could play this one. Very easy to learn and my 8 and 10 year olds play with him too and enjoy the game.
Bought this for my 6-years old grandson, and he loves it.  His parents have the adult version and it was too hard for him.  We played his game today, and it's not boring for even adults.

review_title: Great game for the WHOLE family
review_description: My family loves this game.  This game brings our family together.  My 3 year old helps me. My 6yr old and 9 yr old hold their own and have even won a few times against Dad who always seems to win. I highly recommend this a to all families!
Complicated enough that it's fun for adults but simple enough that my 5 year old caught on pretty quickly.  Like that strategy is needed not just luck.

I have my 6 year old playing it with me a few times/week since xmas. We even had her cousins playing with us recently and they are 7-11. Everyone loves the game. It's not overly complex but it's got some adjustments that drive the person to think through the scenarios. Very nice.

review_title: Great game with some problem solving and strategy needed
review_description: We got this for my newly turned 6 year old for Christmas. He loves board games and is ready for some more complex games. This is the perfect level for him while still stretching his thinking and strategy skills. He really caught on the second time he played but will also grow with him for another year or two.

review_title: The game setup is nice and what you remember from childhood
review_description: The game setup is nice and what you remember from childhood, if you played this growing up. My main disappointment is on the questions for kids. So many of them revolve around pop culture, specific to TV shows, music, and movies. Really? Why can’t questions be about more than that, or ask about more recent historical events rather than the name of Hannah Montana’s third boyfriend. The kids didn’t enjoy it that much because of that. Admittedly we don’t watch a lot of TV but even if we did and they knew the answers, it might make me question what they are “learning” versus what they should be learning. Lots of better games out there to play as a family than this one such as Ticket to Ride or Pandemic. Save your money.

We're having fun playing as a family, but they've really dumbed-down the questions for this version. My kids (12 & 14) can handle many of the "adult" questions, and the kid questions are often ridiculously easy. Also they're often centered around the same thing, like the TV show Glee. Who came up with these questions? Why were they so obsessed with Glee? Why do they think kids watched Glee? It would also be nice if there were more question cards. There are only two small packets (one for kids and one for adults), and we're already seeing the same questions, even though we've only played three times.

review_title: A great family-friendly version of Trivial Pursuit
review_description: I was a huge fan of Trivial Pursuit back in the 80s, when it came out. Both of my boys like trivia, but there was no way we could play the original version. The questions on the kid's side ask current questions about subjects kids would know, while the adult cards ask questions that are similar to the original version of the game. All of the questions have been updated to include recent current events and world records, though.The boys got this for Christmas, and we've played it several times. The kid's questions are easy enough that our six year old has a fair chance of winning, while the adult questions are hard enough to give the kids a good chance.

review_title: Fun educational but not quick or for all ages
review_description: Depending on the age group of your family will determine how well you like the game. I dont agree with the game for all ages.  We played over Christmas in teams and the 5 year old was only in charge of  handing out the pie pieces and putting the questions back in the holder. Until she quit from boredom. The 10 and 12 year old team did pretty good with some of the kid questions. The 7 year old was teamed up with 82 year old pop pop and we switched between kid and adult questions each round. I dont think either one of them cared much either way. There was nothing quick about the game if you follow the rules. We changed it up to speed it up. First ditched the board. The team got to choose what color question they needed for their pie when it was their turn.  If you got a yellow, pink, blue etc  question right you got that color pie piece. Each team only got 1 question per turn. The first team to fill up their pie with each different color wins. That still took over an hour 1/2 to play that way.

My husband and I have six children between 4 and 16. I remember playing Trivial Pursuit with my aunts and uncles growing up but it was a pretty frustrating game for the kids. I thought this "family edition" would be fun for everyone and it is ok but I'm not sure how well it will hold up once the novelty wears off.So far, I've played with the media-savvy 11-, 14-, and 16-year olds several times. My 4-year old likes to roll the die for everyone and give the card to whoever's reading the question and put the wedge in if the answer is right so in that regard, it's a win because she feels like she's playing right along with everybody else.The 14- and 16-year old, in particular, are torn between whether they want to do the grownup cards or the kid cards. The 11-year old definitely wants the kid cards even though a lot of them are super easy for him. With my less-media-savvy 10- and 12-year olds, I think the kid cards might be a little more challenging.Even with four or five people playing, the game moves pretty quickly which is a good thing. It usually takes around 30-40 minutes for a full game.Some of the kid questions off the top of my head:* What Leonardo Da Vinci painting is known for its mysterious smile?* Which of the following is not one of Mario's cousins: Luigi, Yoshi, or Wario?* What is the name of Spongebob's pet snail: Larry, Barry, or Gary?* What is the name of the high school on Glee?* Deltoids, Trapezii, and biceps are examples of muscles, bones, or viruses?* An ankylosaurus can be identified by the horns on its head, a club tail, or because it's the size of a chicken?Some of the adult questions:* What investment banker admitted to running the largest Ponzi scheme in history?* What author is responsible for both Jurassic Park and ER?* What Twitter aficionado was married to Demi Moore?* Which famous composer had 20 children? (this was multiple choice but I don't remember the choices)* Katniss Everdeen is the protagonist of what novel?For both the adult and kid cards, I could do with fewer questions about TV and celebrities because that's just not our thing. Overall, though, we're having fun with it.

review_title: It's a laid back way to play trivial pursuit! Just challenging enough to be fun!
review_description: • comes with box, instructions, foldable board, adult deck, kids deck, blue and yellow deck holders, pie tins, and pie pieces, 1 die (the bags in the picture are mine. it doesn't come with any bags)• the adult questions aren't too hard; the kids' questions aren't too easy. perfect for family.• made of durable materials and designIt's lots of fun! It's a laid back way to play trivial pursuit! Just challenging enough to be fun!

If you're looking for a game that doesn't last for hours and tests your knowledge, than this is the game for you. It allows up to 4 people to play, or ever 8 if you want to have teams with a large party. The yellow kids are much easier than the blue (adult) cards but some of the blue card questions are super hard. It's all around fun to play.

review_title: Good, but adult cards are too easy.
review_description: This Trivial Pursuit game is modified for sped-up game time and age-appropriate questions, but the adult cards are too easy.On this board, every square adds a pie piece to your game piece, making for a faster game for younger ones with shorter attention spans.This game has two sets of cards—one for kids and one for adults. My 6-year-old can get less than half of the questions in the kids’ set without help, so I’d guess that that set is probably best for 8-10-year-olds.  The adult set is maybe best for 10-15-year-olds (just guessing; I don’t have a lot of kids in that age range in my life). Neither set is great for grown-ups. The grown-up cards  are significantly easier than regular Trivial Pursuit, with a large minority of the questions being true/false or multiple choice questions.I suppose the easier adult cards were also designed for faster gameplay, but if you’re a fan of Trivial Pursuit who wants your young child to have a chance at winning, it isn’t going to happen with this game (although, as a dyed-in-the-wool nerd, I did find the pop culture questions challenging—there are many kinds of intelligence and keeping up with pop culture is apparently not one of mine 😂).  If you want to give your child a shot at winning, I recommend that you buy this version AND an adults-only version of Trivial Pursuit, and use the cards from the adults-only version as your adult cards.  Unfortunately, that makes this a rather expensive game.On the other hand, if you want a game that your tween and younger teen can play together, then this might be the perfect thing.  Or if Trivial Pursuit isn’t your cup of tea, but it is your child’s, and you’d just as soon that the adult cards were easy to get it over with, you may appreciate this game unmodified.

We have played this game so many times now!  It moves along much better than the original trivial pursuit because you don't eatin control of the board by answering correctly, play moves on whether you're right or wrong.  Makes for a nice time frame.  Modifying the rules to fit what you like works well here also, we have friends who play it a couple different ways.  Our main group ages are 47, 42 and 17-  we mix the cards up so that it just the luck of the draw whether you get a really easy one, or a really hard one.  That makes for lots of laughs.We have also played with age groups ranging from 11 to 50.  It is the most fun when there are adults and kids mixed up.  We tried it with all adults and it just didn't seem to do as well.  But for families with kids/teenagers/young adults/adults, I HIGHLY recommend it!

This classic-style Trivial Pursuit game is perfect for Family Game Night.My two daughters (first and fourth grade) even play it together.The questions are elementary school-friendly, but are challenging for as high as high school.Example questions are:Which pop singer calls her fans "little monsters"?Which Greek's body was invincible, except for his foot?What is the everyday name for sodium chloride?The game follows the classic Trivial Pursuit fashion. You move your empty pie around the board, collecting different colored wedges.

I searched for a recent 2018-2019 edition and this popped up. Product description confirms a release date of August 2018; however, I received a 2013 version (which I already own). Disappointing purchase.

They have changed the game play to the point where it's a bit flat.  There's no roll again if you get one right. There's no wedge piece spots.  You get a wedge for answering any question in that category. You aren't allowed to go backwards.  It's just weird.  I guess we could just use The old rules but we would have to alter The board. Also the board is cheap.  We'll play it occasionally but we're disappointed in the changes.

review_title: Fun for older elementary and up.
review_description: We play this with my four elementary school aged kids.  It's not a good fit for the kindergartner.  The 4th and 5th graders are a great fit.  The 2nd grader can answer several questions.  The parent questions are appropriately leveled.  When we play teams it's really fun.
The questions are way too easy for the kids,  and insanely difficult for adults.  We've never completed a game because everyone wants to quit after a couple of rounds.

Our two 10-year old daughters now consider this one of their favorite two games (out of many).  The questions are varied, and although some of the kids' questions are quite difficult, it offers our kids a real chance to work at something and beat us fairly on our own turf. It's been good for their self-esteem.  It's quicker than the edition I'm used to, because there are no specific pie award spots like in the original, so it's possible to get through a game in a reasonable amount of time.

review_title: Perfect for Anyone Who's Not an Avid Trivial Pursuit Player
review_description: For people who have never played any other version of Trivial Pursuit, we love it! It's so much fun.But, for someone who used to play Trivial Pursuit a lot in their past, the rules are not the same, which ends the game with many arguments.The only annoying part of this game is that the categories aren't labeled on the board or the cards, so you have to read the categories from the directions sheet.

If you like the original trivial pursuit and are looking for an updated version... this is not it. It's a quick-play version of the original game, and the questions are hard. Most of the kids questions are so hard that the adults couldnt answer them. The game (from start to finish) took maybe 10 minutes, and now it will forever live in my closet because the chances of playing it again are slim to none. Only giving it 2 stars because if you take the new questions and mix them with the original game and use the original game board - youd be gold. Shipping was fast.

review_title: although sometimes the kid questions can be a bit too hard and the adult questions too easy. Still
review_description: The family really is enjoying this game, although sometimes the kid questions can be a bit too hard and the adult questions too easy. Still, it all comes out pretty even in the end, and it's a great game in terms of working for anywhere from 2 to 6 players. It also lasts the right amount of time to play between dinner and bedtime. My 10 year old son loves it.

I used to love playing the original Trivial Pursuit game many years ago, so I couldn't wait to play this one with the family. I felt like some of the kids' questions were really easy, but I guess they're trying to make it fun for even the youngest kids. For example, the first kids' question we pulled was "Who is the Big Red Dog?"Other than that, there was a pretty good mix of questions, and the game play is the same as with other Trivial Pursuit versions.

Trivial Pursuit Family Edition Game

As a longtime Trivial Pursuit lover, I have MANY different versions of this loved game.  Recently, my son has wanted to start playing.  Since most of the versions I have are very difficult, he was frustrated by not knowing the info (he's only 9, and I have genus editions).So, I went looking for a TP we could play together.  Enter Family Edition.  The questions for him are hard enough to be challenging for him, but he still knows enough of the answers to level the playing field.  The only down side is that there aren't any new cards to bulk up the set.  We've played it so much we're circling back to questions he's already learned.As gripes go, that's really minimal.  Overall, I'm very happy with this purchase!

I bought this for my grandson and got to play it with him and his parents a few weeks ago. He is eight. Many of the questions are geared toward middle school but we still were able to filter through to some he would know. The main thing is he loved playing it, and it created fun family time.

We have been playing this game with friends and family over Zoom/Skype/FaceTime since the quarantine began - and it's been SO FUN! We can control the board, while the kids play the parents. Guaranteed laughs and smiles - especially in these unprecedented times. I remember playing the original game as a kid (I'm a 70s baby) and I love that my 9yo enjoys playing as well. Thanks Hasbro!

Wish we'd had this when I was a kid.  I remember having to unsuccessfully play Trivial Pursuit with my parents as a kid.  Needless to say, I hardly ever got a questions correct.  Now, my family can play together.  The kids questions are perfect for my ten year old.  He knows many, but is still challenged by enough.  The adult ones seem pretty reasonable.  (Side note:  My husband plays with the kids cards! Lol!!!)
The game was too juvenile for a six year old.  There was no challenge for any level of player.

review_title: Great for family with younger kids
review_description: Nice game for family with kids on the younger end of the spectrum (say, 6-11 years old). I bought to play with my 13 and 14 year old sons and kid's questions were way too easy for them. We ended up using the adult cards for everyone. Game moves quickly as they've modified the rules in order to do so (to keep the younger one's attention, which is a good thing!), so you can get through a game in maybe 30-45 minutes.

So fun!  My husband and our girls, aged 13 & 18, and I love playing this together.  The girls use the kid questions but even the 13 year old knows many answers to the adult questions as well.  Its much easier than regular Trivial Pursuit, which is good for my handsome, but not so worldly, husband. ;-)

review_title: Great addition to family game nights
review_description: We bought this to add to our family game nights and it was definitely worth it! I have 4 boys ages 7-16 and while some kid cards were difficult for my youngest we would just find one applicable to him. I love how they have kid cards and adult cards. Some nights it’s fun to just play kid cards as adults because they are tricky and make it fun to play.

The game is good, but my only complaint is the relatively small number of cards they provide.  We have owned lots of versions of Trivial Pursuit through the years (Genus, Genus III, Genus IV, Genus V, Millennium, Star Wars, Lord of the Rings, Silver Screen, and one or two more I don't recall), but this has the fewest question cards of any of them.  The kids enjoyed it, though, and the scaled down game play (getting pie every question) makes for a faster game.

I picked this up for my son's 8th birthday. I initially worried that the questions may be too hard, since the game is indicated for ages 8 and up. He's a bright kind who loves trivia, so the Kids' questions are perfect - not too hard and perfectly suites for a kid's worldview. The adult questions, however, could stand to be a little harder. But after years of playing "kids" games, this edition of Trivial Pursuit is a very welcome change of pace!

This is great.  My kids are 13, 11, 7, and 6.  We didn't have the little kids read the questions, because they're a little young.  And there were two Glee questions, which none of my kids have watched.... So when we get a question about something they couldn't know, we choose a different card.The nice thing is that you get a pie for every space.
