If you have searched for travel games and this came up DO NOT BUY IT.

review_title: Not like it used to be
review_description: This game brought back good memories so I ordered it for my grandson. Well let me tell you they just don’t make things like they used to!  This game is difficult to play for several reasons!  First, the picture cards do not sit correctly in the plastic frames so they are always siding out and need readjusting the entire time. Secondly, the characters faces are VERY detailed and complicated to guess making the game long, boring and not all that fun. Skip this one.

How can you not love this game?I purchased this for my 8 year old daughter as we build our board game collection during the pandemic.After growing up playing this game with my sister and it being “hers” so I was only allowed to play it when she allowed... I knew this had to be something I played with my daughter ANY time we want!It’s fun, easy to learn, always changes and never gets old!She has a blast making up names for the people and I have a blast watching her try to remember all of their names lol.I’d definitely recommend buying this for your kids!

We love this game! It’s a great way for young kids to use their adjectives and pay closer attention to detail. I played this as a child and loved it and I’m happy to play again with my own children. One design flaw that I don’t remember as a child is that the faces aren’t held in place by anything. One little tap and half of your game pieces fall off the stand. I thought there used to be slots to slide the face cards into? It makes it really hard to set up for my 4, 6, and 8 year olds and even for me sometimes too. I wish there was a sturdier way for the cards to go onto the stands so they don’t easily fall.

review_title: Not good quality; such a pain to flip the panels back up to start a new game
review_description: While the object is the same, this is not the same guess who you played 20 years ago. This version is very cheaply made. My children can't flip the panels back up after finishing a game and it's a big pain for me to do as well. I have the original game but wanted a second for the kids and this new one is terrible. I'm wondering if this is actually the company that made the original game??

review_title: Not a good replacement for original game
review_description: More rows and smaller pieces make this new version more difficult for younger players. I like the idea of including more types of people but they are weird characterizations. I went to the effort to return this not because of the cost-it's pretty cheap-but because the game maker should have done a better job. They need to go back to the drawing board on this one!

This is very much the exact same game as when I was younger. The set up is fast and my chief complaint is the card holders which still come apart easily and aren't made from the best quality plastic. My Son hates memory games but loves this so it's been a fun compromise.

The concept is so great. Of course we all love the classic Guess Who game. Unfortunately, the quality has gone downhill significantly. You can’t simply flip the board over to get all the characters standing up. You flip it over and maybe 50% flip up and you have to work hard to get the other up (they kind of get stuck). My other complaint is the images of characters. They just are SO computerized and some just look kind of funky. Some of the woman look like they have mustaches from afar. I was excited to introduce the game to my kids but was kind of let down.

This game is the biggest piece of junk I’ve ever received.  It’s small, flimsy, cards aren’t able to stay in place (fall out when you flip down).  I had this game as a child and it was rock solid.  Hasbro cut corners is putting it nicely....it’s 100 times worse than that.  So disappointing.  Needless to say I returned and suggest you save your $$ and buy a different game.

review_title: Mediocre update to the classic game
review_description: I used to love Guess Who so when I saw there was a new version out, I had to pick it up for my niece. The game still has it's classic charm, but it's no where near as well made. It's cheap plastic and the pictures easily slip out of their holders. The pictures also aren't easy to guess as they used to be. Features, such as eye color, gender, etc, used to be much more exaggerated to make it easier for kids. It's still a fun game, but you definitely see they cut corners.

review_title: Guess what's not made like it used to be?
review_description: I have always loved this game and the way that it's great for descriptive language and deductive reasoning skills. Such an easy game to play really. I don't remember there being images in which it's ambiguous. Sorry but one of the images I swore had a mustache but then in much clearer light it's a shadow from his huge nose! Oops. Also, the cards keep sliding and falling out of the trays. We had to tape the cards in because we were so annoyed. There has to be a better way...

review_title: Fun game to play and learn but should be better crafted.
review_description: I loved this game as a child. I used to play it with my father or grandmother. Now that I am a mom I wanted to share this game with my kids. My 6 year old son and my 3 year old daughter both love it now too. It is still a fun game to play and learn about similarities and differences but the craftmenship is not as durable as it was when I was a child. The cards are very flimsy and the plastic does not seem very sturdy. Too bad. It has not broke on us yet though after playing several times. It is still worth buying for under $10.

My sons teacher told me they played this game in class and my son absolutely loved it and suggested it as a Christmas gift! Cool got it! How disappointing it’s such a poorly made game. The cards don’t stay in the slots. After every game you have to put them all back in. It’s just tedious and takes away from the actual game. I’ll be super gluing them in.

The quality and effort needed has gone downhill since I've played like 15yrs ago. Husband never had and I loved this game so I bought it. Had to put together and it was very cheap plastic. So many of the characters are one or the other.  Blue or brown eyes? Glasses or no glasses? Half or more gone already. It's become too easy with many similar characteristics to get rid of so many with one question. Got bored after a few games and not sure we will ever play it. Maybe if we have kids, but I'd rather find the original.

I bought this for my 6 year old & he loves it as much as I did when I was younger. A fun game, quick & easy to play! He has really enjoyed playing!The design changes ARE annoying. The people pictures aren’t attached, so they slide out of the frames/windows. I recall them being like stickers on a solid frame? To avoid having to fix them every game, I spent a few minutes hot gluing the top of the back of the cards to the frame. For $9, it didn’t frustrate me to much to make a fast fix.

Fun game, but four stars because the lack of diversity makes the guessing simple and easy. Need to create a version that requires more questions to figure out the opponent's person. Asking if the person is male or female really narrows the choices. Then hair color, wearing a hat or eye color, are really the only questions to ask. I remember this feeling difficult as a child.

review_title: Fun, but craftsmanship could be better.
review_description: Some of the plastic pieces get jammed so that they all don't flip over smoothly. They sometimes get caught at angles with the hinges popping off slightly on one side. The paper pieces with the faces on them are a thin cardstock material that can easily be bent upon assembly. Once we got them in place though, we haven't had any fall out. Also, My children had differing opinions on whether certain face(s) were he/she (it is also unclear to me) so it makes it a bit more difficult to play with out of the box. Overall it is still fun to play with once we got used to the things mentioned above. I got this on sale during Christmas time, so I gave it 4 stars. If it had been regular price I would have given it 3 stars due to value for price.

This is worse then the guess who I played when I was a little girl. I can see why it’s so cheap. Bought as a gift for my daughter for Christmas because we like to play games together. The hinges for the people suck. They basically pop apart any time you have to move them. My 8 year old is even annoyed with it.Would not recommend. Would not buy again. Would not gift.

Cheap crap! Not worth the money. I only paid $5 for this but it’s not even worth that. The paper cards don’t stay in the plastic frames and the frames don’t flip up and down without getting stuck or popping out. The game is over in 5 guesses or less. We just ended up playing a tiny card game. One of the older versions is so much better.

review_title: Still luck-based, but with some creative ideas that your kids might love
review_description: I bought this after watching several positive YouTube reviews for the game.  Our daughter turned five on Christmas Eve and I've been wanting some games that will challenge her mentally instead of giving her a win simply with dice or a spinner.  (Seriously, spinner games are the worst!)This game...  it kinda tackles that...  Kinda.There are still dice, and there's a simple rule that states you have to declare your goal for the dice before you roll - you can't just go with what the dice gives you.  This is the luck element, and it is the only thing that will dictate success or failure at the game.  Success simply requires enough successful rolls to uncover and reveal the three clues which relate to your randomly-chosen "thief" at the beginning of the game, as well as revealing enough of the suspects until you find the one containing all three clues.  You could get lucky and reveal the clues quickly, matching to a suspect revealed early in the game.  Or you can have some nail-biters where the clues are revealed but the matching suspect is literally the last one left to flip over.  Or you can botch enough rolls and lose.  It helps that the game is cooperative, meaning that you don't feel as personally victimized by the luck.  However, get a few older people around the table, and you might get someone blaming someone else for not getting enough successful rolls.The skill is simply understanding how to determine which of the suspects is innocent or guilty based on the clues revealed and the results from the clue-finding device (which itself is fun to work with.)  To an adult this is a no-brainer, but to a five-year-old it's a bit more complex.  The plus side - and the reason I ultimately like the game - is the sheer thrill a child experiences when they connect the dots and nail the thief.A few other notes: the game takes up a decent amount of real estate.  The board is rather large, and you're required to lay 16 cards either around the board or otherwise nearby.  This is in no way a complaint, but just a head's up - as far as kids games go, this one is rather large.Also, the cards feel a tad thin, and my daughter already bent one just sliding it into the clue-finder piece.  The theme and gameplay might work for a young kid, but the cards won't stand up to a lot of abuse.  In addition, the game arrived with the cards rubber-banded instead of the usual plastic wrap, meaning many of our cards were "marked" on arrival.  The detective hats and fox pieces are a soft plastic that allow a little bending (which is good), and the dice are nicely printed with vibrant colors.All in all the game is a good, if not short-term addition to the collection; kids will find it much more replayable than adults (kids can even play solo if they wanted to), with a fun theme that lightly encourages teamwork, albeit with an inescapable element of luck.

review_title: Fun Game to introduce Big Kid board games
review_description: Bought this for my 4.5 year old as an introductory deductive logic game. At first, I was pretty disappointed by the simplicity of the logic needed for the game. Basically, you find out if the guilty fox does or does not have a particular item on their person. If the guilty party does have the item, then you eliminate all the suspects that do not have that item and if the guilty party does not have the item, then you eliminate all the suspects that do have the item. Simplistic enough that my 4.5 year old caught on pretty quick and was able to keep or eliminate suspects without assistance. So why the 5 star rating if the game was not what I hoped it would be? It is because my daughter LOVES this game and she has never liked board games all that much. Also the game does teach a fair amount of 4.5-7 year old appropriate strategy and has just a little bit of complexity to it which she has never had the patience to learn for any other game we have tried. I see it as a great way to introduce 4-7 year old kids to big kid board games, that a 4-7 year old will probably love.

review_title: A great deduction game to play with kids that teaches basic ...
review_description: A great deduction game to play with kids that teaches basic logic and tests memory.  Three year old child just grasps the decisions and makes some errors in logic.  Five year old clearly makes good decisions based on logic and memory.  Seven year old finds it easy and will quickly out grow it.  The play length is ideal for playing a quick game with Dad before dinner.  Recommended but only for playing with kids aged 3-7.

review_title: FANTASTICALLY DESIGNED GAME FOR SMALL CHILDREN
review_description: The folks at Department of Recreation designed this game and did an awesome job! We just got it a few days ago and my just-turned-5 year old can't stop talking about it. She loves it! As her mom, I'm enjoying it too. It's nice to have a game that's at least mildly interesting for grown-ups who play along with their children (as opposed to things like Candy Land).This game is sort of like "Clue" for little kids. A fox stole a potpie and you have to figure out which fox it was before s/he escapes into the foxhole. There are SUSPECT cards, each with the picture and name of a fox. Then there are THIEF cards - one for each of the suspects. One of the THIEF cards is chosen (but kept secret) in the beginning of the game. You then spend your turns either revealing SUSPECTS or finding CLUES. The clues are things like hat, scarf, glasses, umbrella, etc and whether or not the THIEF has those items. For example, you might find out that your guilty fox is wearing a hat and pearls but does not have an umbrella or glasses. Once you've revealed the SUSPECT card that matches all your clues, you know who the guilty fox is and can announce it. But if you aren't able to figure out the clues fast enough, the fox gets away. There is dice-rolling involved (but no numbers on the die, just symbols) for an element of luck/chance.One of the coolest features of the game is the "magic clue revealer" thingy. It's a plastic case that you slide the chosen THIEF card into at the beginning of the game. Then, every time you get a CLUE, you place the clue (i.e. a token with a picture of a hat on it) onto a spot on the revealer. Then you slide open a door and you will see either a red or green dot, indicating whether your THIEF does or does not have that item (i.e. the hat) on him. This part is a lot of fun for the little ones!I'd say this game is great for the ages of about 4-8. It teaches great critical thinking skills,like logic and deduction.

This is a fun cooperative game, where players work together to rule out suspects and find the guilty fox before he is gone.  Our 7 and 10-year-old kids love this game, and we adults enjoy playing this game with them. I highly recommend this game! Please mark if you find my review helpful. Thank you so much!

review_title: What a lovely, clever game for a family with young kids!
review_description: Today this arrived and we played it already and loved it! Board games are one of the best ways I have found to bond with my two young sons. So, I went on a shopping spree for them on Amazon and this game was one of the suggestions made by Amazon. They based it on several other games I had purchased by this same game company - games we also have enjoyed.First thing is the packaging and contents:  the box, the board, the tokens - everything is just so nice! Really fine quality. This company really puts in effort. I feel loke I got what I paid for.The game itself is so clever!!!! I am 37 years old but i found myself hooting and hollering in relief and joy when after my third and last try with the dice rolled in our favor! We narrowly won our first game. The fox was just a couple bad rolls away from escaping.This game is definitely worth it for little ones. It is the perfect middle ground of difficulty level for both my 7 year old and 4.5 year old.It has that collaborative factor that brings us together. Although the game works by turn taking all involved are still working as a team. We made decisions as a team if the person with the next turn should choose to reveal suspects or clues.There are 16 suspect cards and the decoder cards are a sequence of dots- hard to explain without showing it but let me say you will not memorize those 16 decoder cards no matter how many times you play the game. So, it will never get old. Very clever developers.

This is a really great game! I played it today with my 5 year old and my husband and we all really enjoyed it. It has a really unique premise - a child-sized mystery. On each turn you must decide whether you’re going to attempt to reveal a clue or reveal 2 suspects. You work together throughout the game to try to catch the thief by using the clues to eliminate suspects. If you don’t roll either 3 clue icons or 3 suspect icons on your turn - the Fox gets to move 3 spaces closer to making an escape. It’s very well done and super cute. There is an element of chance, and a lot of problem solving & logic. Can’t wait to play again!

review_title: Highly recommended game for 4+ year olds. A great gift!
review_description: Great game for 4+ year olds - and is actually fun for the adults playing as well!This game takes concepts we've seen in other classic games – Yahtzee (the re-rolling of dice), Guess Who (the elimination of "suspects" based on "clues") and Clue (moving around a "map" to find clues) – but combines them in a way that feels fresh and fun. Plus, the added collaborative aspect is well implemented, too.I also like that they err on the side of the game being too easy than too punishing - e.g., you'll usually be able to make it to the next "clue site" with one turn; had they spaced them out even slightly more, it would have made the game drag, especially for a little one.As it stands, it's well-paced fun, with just the right balance of "thinking" and luck.Highly recommended!

review_title: but this is pretty fun. In this cooperative game
review_description: Some games that are geared for my kids make me want to stick a fork in my eye (I'm looking at you, Chutes and Ladders), but this is pretty fun. In this cooperative game, all the players are trying to figure out the identity of the fox thief by revealing clues and checking out suspects. The process of the game encourages logic, deduction, and analytics, but don't tell my kids that. Game play didn't take too long (maybe 20 minutes?) and was enjoyed by the whole family, from the 4 year old to the 60 year old grandpa. (Younger than 4 would probably lose interest)

review_title: Better than many other kid games
review_description: I have played this game with my kids many times and still enjoy it when we get to play. As a father that has many board games and wants to pass that love on to my kids - I get tired of playing games like Hi-Ho Cherrio or Clue Jr over and over as the games just feel stale and repetitive. This game allows children to play the same game over and over but solve the problem from different angles and learn great board game skills along the way. This game has the randomness of dice throws, decision making, a "countdown" timer to a win or lose condition, pawn movement, problem solving, and a memory element. I encourage every parent with younger kids to try this one out. I play this with my 4 year old and 6 year old regularlyand while the game is fun the best thing about it is that my 4 year old stays for the whole game because it holds his interest. Hope your family enjoys it as much as we do.

We were so excited to play this game! Got it all set up, started playing, having fun. Then we get to the end and realize somewhere things had gone wrong. The decoder did not reveal who the suspect was. Either the ‘Thief’ cards were misprinted, or the decoder is defective because they did not line up with the clue tokens. We tried multiple cards. None worked!

I had heard great things about this game, and was excited when it came. My son and I played a round and loved it, except when we got to the end, and there was only one suspect left, it didn't match the THIEF card. So I went through and looked - out of the 16 suspect cards and 16 thieve cards (which obviously need to match up), only ONE matched. The names were different on the cards!!  OK, nothing customer service can't fix - just send me a matching set of cards. So I reached out and got this response: "Please allow around 10-14 days from the date of this email for delivery - a bit longer for international destinations."  that email was written on 1/20/20 and it's now 2/13/20 and NOTHING. I've event followed up with the person who sent me the email, and have heard nothing back after that original email.  I'm so disappointed.

This game may have good gameplay and replay-ability once you figure it out, but I’m really disappointed with everything else about the design of the game, particularly at getting you quickly to the point of actually playing.First of all, the instructions are lengthy and dumbed down to the point of handholding, so you have to walk through the entire set of instructions every time you reference them to find the simplest information. This probably doesn’t matter once you’ve played a few times, but there are a lot of mechanics to this game that are not self evident, so you end up having a VERY slow setup and first few plays.It says 5 and up, but even the most gifted 5yos I have met are going to have a hard time deciphering these instructions and getting things setup without the help of a child with 5th grade+ reading comprehension. And the dumbed down nature and lack of organization to the instructions will frustrate older kids and test the patience of adults.Second, the uninspired game board and graphics add insult to the injury of poor instructions. The game board has NO LABELS and low contrast - so nothing stands out, and painfully, the instruction indicating what all the unlabeled spaces mean is not separate from the sequential setup/gameplay instructions, just annoyingly mixed along the way with setup AND gameplay instructions.The concept and quality of all the disparate mechanical parts is low. There is a clue tool that is poorly designed, manufactured, and nearly unintelligible in its function without those horrible instructions. There are so many better ways to add this functionality to the game with fewer dissimilar pieces.The worst is that the first few times through, clues didn’t work and the game completion actually FAILED due to incomplete hole punches that obscured the clues. This kind of quality control just further complicated an awkward design and really detracted from gameplay.We tried to play three games and were so annoyed and unimpressed that we lost interest and will just give it away to another family now.Other irritating things about this game...The box is twice as thick as necessary to contain the contents and this brand includes a thick foldout advertisement for all their other games in every box that doesn’t really fit anywhere but the garbage can and is basically just photos.

If the decoder worked as it is supposed to, this would 100% be a new favorite game in our house. The actual game play is great, my 4 year old and 14 year old were having a great time playing, which is rare finding a game both ages like. Our box had a defective decoder (I’ve seen others mention it now too when researching). It wasn’t obvious to us, until we finished the game and couldn’t figure out why our last suspect wasn’t correct. When we put the suspect card into the decoder facing the right way and push the card all the way in, apparently the card is actually going down far enough (but for some unexplainable reason, if we put it in backwards, the car goes in lower and would be in the right position...I can’t for the life of me figure out why because the card is the same thickness so direction shouldn’t matter as far as how far down it will go, but we can’t play with the card backwards.) My engineer husband said he will get a small saw blade later and see if he can fix the decoder so this game will still work, but unfortunately, since we didn’t realize it wasn’t working correctly until after we played the first time, my kids have now soured on this game and aren’t interested in playing again (hopefully someday they will).

review_title: The game is defective. Very disappointing.
review_description: This game is a fantastic concept. I love that it's cooperative instead of competitive, so my younger kids have an opportunity to be a part of the win. I wanted to give it 5 stars, but our game is defective, so I just can't at this time. If the company replaces the defective item or sends a replacement, I will update. The clues and clue decoder work together to tell you what garments the thief is wearing. Every thief card has 3 green dots that are revealed one by one with the clues that are inserted into the decoder to let you know that the thief has on glasses, a scarf, an umbrella, etc... Well not a single one of our thief cards line up with the viewfinder in the clue decoder, so only 1 of 3 green dots are possible to be viewed after collecting all of the clues. This results in every single suspect being eliminated...and it being impossible to win the game. I don't know if it's the decoder or the deck of thief cards that are defective, but it was very disappointing for my 5 year old who was gifted this...especially since we didn't realize the defect until the suspects were all eliminated and the game couldn't be won.

This game is so great! We call this the “Sly Fox Game”. Perfect for a 5 year old and adults (I think I love it as much as the 5 yr old does). The complexity of thought involved is extraordinary compared to some other games—strategy, memory, counting, deductive reasoning, chance (the dice; choice of thief), cooperation, reading (names), etc. Each play involves several decisions or calculations : try for clues or suspects; if clues, how many spots and what direction?; is the spot white/green and therefore does the thief have x ?; if yes/no, are any of the visible suspects ruled out or still in? Do we have enough info? Should we guess? The game is engaging and fun. It may be that one day we know the thieves well enough that we can guess early on, but there are enough thieves to keep a 5 yr old (and even an adult who isn’t trying to memorize the suspect cards) from easily identifying all the thieves by their details. The thief cards are very attractive with rich colors and fun images. The 4 squares per clue box makes the clue spots accessible and yet the distance between some provides some challenge. The option to have the fox move more or fewer spots at a time in a given game is a simple (practical and elegant) way to make the game easier or more challenging for kids. Added fun, detective hats can be replaced with any other small toy (miniature paw patrol dogs work great ; lego superheroes do too). Can’t say enough good things about the game.

This game was perfect for us and our almost 5 year old.  We played twice as soon as it arrived and had a ton of fun.  The first time through we pretty much identified the thief immediately, so I was afraid it might be too easy, but the second time through we ended up down to two possible suspects and had to scramble to find relevant clues before the thief escaped.  I love that the box has a spot for everything, so it stays organized without adding ziplock baggies to the mix.  I will recommend this game to others with young kids.Oh, the directions did not mention whether you can go to the same clue space more than once, but we determined it made way more sense not to be able to, and that’s how we played.  Once a clue was placed on that square, we did not revisit that square.

review_title: Excellent cooperative game for a six year old
review_description: We were desperately looking for games to play as a family while we have been staying at home during the pandemic. Emotions are running a bit high and competitive games are sometimes ending in tears. Unfortunately, a lot of cooperative games are not challenging enough to entertain kids older than pre-school age. This game turned out to be a big win for us. There is definitely some luck but it requires some basic deductive reasoning to beat the fox.In this game, all players are competing against the fox to figure out 'who done it.' There are 16 different possible fox thieves and each has a matching suspect card. You pick one thief card without looking and put the card in a special plastic holder. (Other thief cards are not used during the game and are returned to the box.) Suspect cards are placed face down around the board, four per side. On the board, each player gets a game piece and there is a fox. There are also 'clues' that are either stacked or placed face down nearby. Each 'clue' is a small card that fits into the special plastic holder.Players then take turns rolling three special dice that have eyes and paw prints on the six sides. You must declare prior to rolling if you want to "reveal suspects" or "search for clues." Then you have three rolls to match the dice with your declaration--eyes to reveal suspects or paws to search for clues. You get to hold the 'correct' dice on a roll and only re-roll the 'wrong' dice. If you get all three dice to match what you declared by the third roll, you get to take that action.Revealing suspects: The player gets to turn over two suspect cards. Each suspect is dressed a certain way and may or may not be wearing things such as a scarf, pearls, white gloves, umbrella, flower, etc.Searching for clues: The player moves their game piece on the board the number of paw prints shown on the dice (ranges from 3-6). The goal for moving your game piece is to make it to open spots on the board that allow you to search for clues. You can typically reach a spot in one or two turns. Once on a spot, the player takes a 'clue', which is an item that the thief may or may not be wearing (scarf, pearls, white gloves, etc.) and places that card into the special holder. A window slides open to reveal if the thief is or isn't wearing that item. Using deductive reasoning, the team can then look at the suspect cards that are revealed to determine whether or not the suspects are innocent. Innocent suspect cards are returned to the box.Didn't match all three dice in three rolls? The fox moves forward 3 spaces toward its fox hole.Play continues like that, eliminating innocent suspects by revealing suspects or clues. The goal is to get down to one final suspect--who is the guilty fox--before the fox gets away by reaching his fox hole.There are some variations explained in the instructions, but those are the basics.I would highly recommend this game for kids over age 6. Kids under 5 would need help with the reasoning part, but could participate. It might be a bit too simplistic for kids over around age 8.

review_title: Perfect for a 5 year old who hates to lose
review_description: As a huge fan of board games myself, it's been a long time dream to introduce my son to board games.  So far, games like candy land and memory have not gone well... he's ultra competitive and hates losing or even having a bad turn.  We try to take it back to basics, and focus on the fun, and learning how to take turns... yea, none of that has worked for him yet.  But then I realize some of my favorite board games are cooperative and I started researching... that's when I found this game.  It took me weeks to just order it, thinking this might just be a waste of money, but I'm so glad I did now!This game has been a breath of fresh air for us.  Yesterday three of us sat down to play this for the first time and it was a complete success from start to finish.  He loved it.  We won the two games we played, and only the first time did it start looking a little iffy.  The second time it wasn't even close.  It would take a lot of unlucky rolls to lose this game.  But I don't think it matters.  If anything he's learning through this game that we can have fun together.  He waited patiently for his turn and was happy because things are happening on every turn.Adults may get bored by this game eventually.  The strategy is simple and there aren't a lot of difficult decisions to make.  But it's mostly fun watching your little figure out how to use the secret clue decoder and eliminate suspects.  I'm not sure how many times we'll play this one, but I like that it's something that's fun for now and probably when friends come over too.

My children are 9, 9, 7 and 4. They all LOVE this game. They have played it so much since we received it that we had to make up multiple new ways to play. The board, cards and box are all designed so well and the art is engaging! I enjoy the game also which is great because there are some children’s games that they love and I have to force myself to play. Ha!The only “flaw,” and this won’t be an issue for everyone, is that after my children played several times they had memorized the cards so they didn’t need to uncover any suspects to guess the thief. This could use an expansion deck so there are more fox options and then the game wouldn’t be quite as easy to beat.

We got this game for our 3 and 5 year old kids for Christmas.  We have played it about 5 times in the past two days.Pros:  Super cute, creative way to try and discover which fox stole the pie.  It is great for young kids to look at the foxes and make predictions and inferences.  It has also been fun for me as an adult to play, which says a lot since lots of kids games can easily get boring.  There are several cute fox cards and the goal is to use the clues to find out if it was the fox wearing the hat, gloves, necklace, etc.Cons:  It comes with a large game board, but I don't see the need to visit all the spots on the game board.  You could almost get away with staying in one corner of the board and going back and forth to look for clues.  I wish the game board had better features so that you wanted to visit more of the board.Overall, a great game and I am happy we got it.

We love cooperative games, but most are super simple or so easy we get bored of them quickly. This is super fun to play since there's still some difficulty to it but we can work together and usually figure out "who did it." We were missing one of the clue pieces, but it didn't seem to affect game play and when I contacted the company, they sent a replacement for free. I definitely recommend this to everyone as a family game and have given it as a gift too.

review_title: A really fun game for small kids and their parents
review_description: This particular game was bought for my six-year old and it is a very enjoyable game for both child and parents.  The game is sort of like Clue but very oriented towards the younger kids.  The game teaches kids about luck and consequences (trying to roll a particular result, otherwise the fox gets closer to his escape), rudimentary map reading skills (how to move the pieces on the board as it is very two-dimensional), logic (not only in the positive, but also in the negative with clues -- culprit may wear a top hat but does not wear a scarf), application (putting clues together with suspects to narrow down to the culprit), and team work (the game is a team endeavor to capture the guilty member and not trying to hide clues for one individual to win; everyone wins or everyone loses).Though this game is fun to play, the game is still oriented for small kids.  Once the child matures to the level of figuring out the game logic by ways of doing it with a few clues, it will lose some of its luster.  Again, it is a great game for small kids and their parents wanting to spend time with them.

review_title: Great game. Kudos for the perfect storage box.
review_description:
I've got dozens of kids games and this one may be the best.-Co-op gameplay is great for kids. Different skill levels can all play together happily.-Simple to play yet with enough choices to keep things interesting - choose to look for clues or reveal suspects.-Deductive reasoning component makes kids think but is still simple enough for a 4-year-old to grasp.-Illustrations are attractive and fun.-Perfect storage box which is an often overlooked but extremely valuable part of a board game. This one has plastic molding that creates compartments for every different card or piece in the game. Everything looks nice and neat when put away. Makes clean up fun and makes set up and play easy.-I've played this game dozens of times and I estimate we win 90% of the time which I think is good for kids.This game is perfect - just get it. I also highly recommend 

Monza

  .

review_title: Returned. Second Game Still Defected But Playable. Fun Game Though
review_description: Decoder was busted. Card wouldn’t slide in far enough to reveal clues. Returned product. Got another quickly. Decoder is also made incorrectly on the new game. This time you can sort of push the card in while holding it tightly and shove it past the plastic “lip” defect in the decoder to make it work. As other reviews have mentioned there is a flaw in many copies of this game which is very unfortunate. I would still say this is an amazing game. Very fun and great cooperative critical thinking. My kids enjoy it. It’s just very unfortunate that quality control is an issue for this particular game. If you are buying it for yourselves I still say it’s a good game and worth the risk that the decoder is messed up. If it’s a gift do not risk it

review_title: You can’t actually lose the game
review_description: The fox escaping which causes you to lose the game has to go to far, even with the ‘difficult’ setting. You can uncover all three clues, and flip all the suspects, and the fox still won’t get within 10 squares (two moves) of the end.  My son still likes it (5.5 years) but there should still be some chance of losing. The other cooperative game we got him, Mole Rats in Space has genuine risk of loss and decisions to make. We still win about 3/4 of the time, but the losing does matter.

review_title: Simple, engaging, and fun family game!
review_description: Both my 4 year daughter and my 7 year old son love this game.  And I love playing it with them.  It’s a great cooperative game and I love seeing them get excited for each other and me when we roll what we need.  The gameplay is simple and involves memory (you have to remember which clues are on the suspect and which are not) as well as deductive reasoning (determining which suspects should be removed based on the clues).  We did not win the first time we played as there was a little confusion over the paw prints on the dice but have won many times since then.  The kids have even been known to pull it out and play by themselves.  Highly recommend this game!

We love this game. I happened to stumble across this game at a discount store for next to nothing. The box was damaged, looked up the price on Amazon read the reviews and thought "what a steal" I'll take it for $2.It's very easy to learn. I like that it's a cooperative game. We have several of those types of games. This one is more challenging then those. 8yr okd and 5yr old can play on their own.This game is so well loved that we have purchased it several times from Amazon to pass the love of the game on to others.It has also led us to discovered other games that Gamewright has made and we have really enjoyed everything we have played from them.

This was one of a stack of games that arrived two days after Amazon's giant sale on board games. I have been on a hunt for games my 5 year old can play that aren't awful (candyland and snakes and ladders are not going to happen.) This was a CLEAR winner. He can do every aspect of this without any adult help. Bonus points, the 9 year old ALSO loves it, AND it's fairly quick.Some of our family's infatuation with this game COULD come from our incurable silliness. We accuse suspects, we lament the fox's progress toward victory. My 5 year old plays the bad cop side of good cop/bad cop toward whoever the lead suspect is. When the previous round's culprit is cleared of wrongdoing, we praise him for turning his life around. But the point is it's fun, and the kids beg me to play again and again. Highly recommend.

I love the concept of this game - it's kind of a Clue / Guess Who? combination of sorts. It's fun to play - and has a few variations to make it more difficult which is nice.But...I don't love the part where you have to pick if you are going to roll for suspects or for clues - so we just skip and you pick after your first roll. No biggie really.In my opinion though, the game board could have been cleaner. There are too many spaces to move from place to place to get to clues. I think it's unnecessary.  It could have been either a much simpler board OR just no need for players to move spaces at all - just roll 3 dice to get 3 suspects or 3 clues. Wish the board had spaces for the fox to move -- and then spaces on the board for the clue cards - those not used yet - and then a space for the "yes" clues and a space for the "no" clues.

review_title: My kids love this game, and I love that's it's cooperative
review_description: Got this game for my kids for Christmas and they have loved it.  It is really great that they work together and they love getting to roll the dice a bunch of times.  My only issue, and it might just be with the one I got, is that the contraption that holds the card to give hints as to who the thief is- isn't sized well. It's REALLY difficult to get a clue card into the slot so that the clues will show up correctly, my kids can't do it alone and have bent a bunch of cards out of shape attempting to.  I have tried to shave around the inside to see if that would fix it, but I still always have to put the cards in, and it's difficult even for me.

review_title: Great game, with modifications to make it more difficult
review_description: We really enjoyed this game. We read reviews beforehand, and disagree with the complaints about quality - we felt the quality of the cards was just fine. Our 4.5 year old instantly loved this game. The decoder design is pretty neat, and easy enough for a 4 year old to operate. Our only complaint is that it is too easy to win if you play by the rules. To make it harder to win, we increased the fox's movement to 5, reduced the number of roles from 3 to 2, and made a rule that someone couldn't go to a clue spot that had already been visited. With those rules in place, the game became more challenging. I'd also recommend more suspects, more clues to have to remember, etc. All in all, we love this game and highly recommend it!

Update 1/20/20 - exchanged it hoping the new one will work. Unfortunately not. I give up. It seemed like a fun game but I can’t keep exchanging it.Defective - like the other reviews, either the thief card or the suspect cards are defective. We played it for the first time and eliminated all the suspects, then looked at the thief card - matched it to the decoder and realized there is a defect. I do wish to get the game replaced as we enjoyed playing it.

My 5 year old niece and I played this game for the first time tonight. She loved it so much it kept her attention for 3 straight games. I really liked that the game is based on team work, and I'd say that she did too, since she was high-fiving me anytime either of us got to a clue or knocked out a suspect. The concept is great, but the clues were a bit confusing with the red and green options, we had to keep reminding each other which were the clues to find suspects and knock out others. This game works on both team work and deductive reasoning skills.

Confused at all 5 star reviews here🤷‍♀️1) I needs to agree that cards are way too think for this age group. Considering there is a decoder - Card’s get bent and creased easily, so bunch of them get marked.2) There is literally no challenge. We played this game so many times and we have never been outfoxed. Never. What’s the challenge if you always know you’re going to win? It’s either the fox needs to go more spaces (a lot more), or instead of flipping 2 suspect cards- get 1 instead. And so that said, the game gets BORING.3) I wish game board manufacturers would ditch the idea of quad-folding boards. They are really annoying.4) Other than that, yeah.. it’s a “good game”... I wish I could return it and get something that’s more captivating and keeps you interested.

We  wanted to get a board game that teaches team work for our 4 years old. We opened the box, the quality was amazing. The game is  a detective game and it was really fun. You have to work together to solve the case and find the thief(the fox) before he/she gets away. Personally I hate most of the board games when you have to put them away, you can only put all the pieces in the box and they all mixed up and very annoying. The best part of this game besides it is fun, and educational, the pieces has its place to go when you are ready to put them away. The game comes with a tray that every game pieces can be neatly put away! Buy it!

review_title: A fun game with no winners or losers
review_description: So the beauty  of this game, if you have children who get upset when they lose, is that this game has no winners or losers. All the players work together (in a very uncomplicated way) to outfox the fox. It seems like a game that would appeal to the preschool age, but our 6 year old and 8 year old grandchildren really enjoyed the game, as well as our 4 year old. It's refreshing to see them all crossing their fingers in hopes that the other players (siblings) will be able to prevent the fox from winning the game.  The instructions are a bit weak, in fact, we had to resort to YouTube. Really? For a game designed for 5 year olds and up? But you can do some improvising and interpret the rules as you wish and still have fun.

This is a wonderful, collaborative game that lets kids practice logical reasoning skills in a team-based way (all players are on a team vs. the fox/thief). A good way to play this with kids of different ages or ability levels is to have the older or more advanced kids verbally share their reasoning as they eliminate suspects based on clues, to help the younger kids follow along. Additionally, older kids enjoy pausing the game for a few minutes to look at the remaining suspects and predict which clues would be most helpful in finding the thief.

Bought this for my 4 year old daughter's birthday back in April.After a couple play throughs at the time she figured it out enough to play and have fun with us.By 4 and a half she totally understood the game and actually enjoyed it.She's still not yet 5, and asks to play it at least a couple times a week.The best part? This game is actually pretty fun for the parents too.It's mostly (but not entirely) luck based, and there is some decision making and deductive reasoning skills.And since it's cooperative, you're engaged even when it's not your turn.Great game for families! And I'm sure it'll be good fun for her to play with her little brother in a couple years.Skip Candy Land, and get Outfoxed!

review_title: FUN and exciting game with some minor adjustments to the game play.
review_description: We've made the game way more exciting by putting the clue chips on the board (not part of the instructions). This makes the game way more interesting as then there is purpose to moving the hats.  Otherwise, you move between two clue spots and just keep capturing clues.  My students love the inductive and deductive reasoning involved and rip the code checker out of anyone's hand to reveal the outcome.  It is like opening a present every time you get to check.  They love thinking through who might have done it and who can be ruled out.  It does not require capturing all the clues to solve the "who done it."  This is not explained in the game, but when looking at the cards closely (adults can take the lead on this), you can identify how many clues you need to find the thief.

My 5 and 6 year old nieces are obsessed with this game and want to play it every single day. They caught on pretty quickly to the rules but haven't grown tired of it after nearly 2 months of daily play. Often they will want to play it 3 or 4 times in a row. The concept is cute and it's a group game so the competition factor is low. That's good for one of my nieces who gets very stressed out by pressure and the idea of failing. She seems to love the team effort. It's also got some great learning skills built into it, like memory, visual cues, and counting. Great game all around!

My five year old son and I have a blast with this game.  It's not just another board game where you move pieces from spot to spot, and having to figure out "who done it" is exciting for him, as well as entertaining enough for me to enjoy playing the game as well!  I bought this as a lightening deal because the picture caught my eye (I love foxes) and am so glad that I grabbed it!!!

Got this to play with my 6 year old and we both have a good time with it. She really like Clue Jr and Outfoxed combines a lot of those concepts, but the thing I like is that there is less set up and clean up to it. Can be a little less fun when your first suspect lines up with first two clues as you basically can nail your guy right from the start, but overall those games are far and few in between. Games take about 15min; replay ability seems decent enough but not something you will probably keep going back to on a constant basis.

My 4 year old LOVES this game. We’re a gaming family and are always hunting for fun and educational games. We love this because 1. It’s coooerative. We all win or we all lose as a family. 2. It’s quick. We can play in 15-20 minutes. 3. Great board design. My daughter loves the pictures on the board (she calls it her map) and the “Sherlock Holmes hats.” And 4. The logic involved. Using clues, kids deduce who can be a suspect and who should be eliminated as a suspect. This has become one of our favorite family games and it’s one of our favorites to gift to her friends!

My kids just turned 4 and 6 and both enjoyed. It’s a cross between Clue and Guess Who? I actually really enjoyed as well. It was interesting and a pretty quick game. I saw reviews of decoders not working and can only guess they used the wrong set of cards or put it in backwards, otherwise I don’t see how this is possible. Wonderful game and highly recommend for any age. After playing a few times, my 6 year old could probably play without adult help, but I’m happy to play this one.

This is my favorite game to play with our kids (ages 5 and 9), and we love to play and own a lot of board games, so that says a lot! It can be difficult to find games that don't result in sibling rivalry, that don't repackage what an existing board game already does, and that are easy to understand for younger kids while still being fun for older kids (and adults). This game is fun to play, creatively developed, and well-made. I noticed the few criticisms that exist are mostly about missing parts or confusing instructions, but all of our pieces were there (and the game is such a good one that it's worth exchanging if you happen to be missing parts), and if the instructions are unclear, playing a single round should help them become clear. Over all, it's an excellent game and I can't recommend it more highly!

review_title: Lots of excellent reviews here but my family did not take to ...
review_description: Lots of excellent reviews here but my family did not take to this game, not helped by the confusing instructions. I do like the collaborative game play but think "Race to the treasure", the other collaborative game Santa brought the kids, is a lot more fun :)

review_title: Collaborative, game--a mix between Clue and Memory
review_description: You know what I like best about this game? It's a collaborative game--no competition. I can always tell when my kids have pulled out Outfoxed, because I hear them rooting for one another and cheering for each other. They're all ON THE SAME SIDE! It's brilliant! It's a simple game--my five-year-old plays it with ease. Her older sister (10) and brother (8) enjoy this one too and they often pick it first for family game nights. A real winner in this one.

GREAT GAME - ages 5 and up... with such a low starting age you may think that older kids wouldn't like it - but my 14 y/o daughter really enjoys playing with her 6 y/o sister.Try making the game harder by increasing the steps the thief takes... it so fun to see little kids get all dramatic when its a "close game."The only complaint would be that the manufacture should get a new die to cut the "clue markers" to better match the receiving indention on the plastic clue decoder - or the other way around, fix the injection molds for the "clue decoder" - us and everyone that plays with us has difficulty placing the clue markers in, let alone holding them in place while simultaneously sliding the exposure door open underneath.

review_title: Outstanding game that encourages deductive reasoning!
review_description: My wife and I have played this game the past two nights with our 3.5 year old son. He loves it, and it's a really great game to discuss some simple logic. The game is simple enough for a young child to play but complex enough to not bore adults in a quick game. I think we'll have fun playing this game for years to come and look forward to our son showing his friends and younger sisters how to play. Our son is already able to complete the setup on his own--he just needs some basic guidance on the rules of play and some small guidance with the logic. It's really fun!

review_title: Hilarious game to play with friends. Fun to play with adults or kids, good icebreaker.
review_description: I first played this game at a friend's house years ago and kind of forgot about it even though it was a blast. When I saw it on amazon I remembered how fun it was and ordered it. It's great game because it takes seconds to learn and is super fun to play with any age group. It's goofy so it's fun whether you win or lose. So far it's held up great and it's wooden so it looks classic enough to leave out on a table and play any time.
It was a game and it was from China I wish I had known that before I purchased it NEVER AGAIN!
I bought this for my grandson for his birthday but everyone loves to play!  A big hit.Good for all ages (well, maybe 4+).
This is a super fun game!  My 5 & 7 year old love it and their dad and I join in too!  It isn’t too big, so it can be put away easily and is made well.
So much fun!!!! :) the only thing I wish is that it would stick to the table somehow!:)
My grandchildren enjoyed this game and had fun challenging each other.  They are 10 and 7.  Set up is a snap
Absolutely fantastic game despite how simple it is. Kids and adults will love playing highly recommend.
Very fun

review_title: You know it’s good because I hate it so much.
review_description: If I have to play this game one more time I’m going to commit myself to a mental ward. That’s how I know it’s a good game. My kids want to play it over and over and over. It’s a great first board game for kiddos and my 2 year old can play. It can also be monotonous and repetitive for those over the age of 30. Purchase at your own risk.

Loved  this game :-) We play it with our 3 yr old granddaughter. A few tips:-have a sandwich baggy ready to hold the fruits when the game is over. No pouch is provided for storage.-lift the game board out of the box, and firmly tape the corners. This will make the board a lot more sturdy.The game is easy to understand, easy to play, and granddaughter did beat us .Our G.d is very into "small" things, she enjoyed placing the fruits on the trees as much as the actual game itself.

Great game and super easy for my 3 year old to understand, but SO. MANY. SMALL. PIECES.  I guess I should have thought of that first.  Within days the minuscule cherries were turning up in every nook and cranny of the house.  They went missing quickly and now we no longer have a full game.  Would recommend being very strict with putting this away immediately and out of reach.
My 4 year old loved it. I also like how Amazon's version has different colored fruits which is a big improvement over the standard original version.

review_title: It's a decent game. No Chutes and Ladders, but then what is?
review_description: It's a fun little game to play with a toddler.The concept is simple enough for my 3 year old to easily master. There is a spinner with about 6 or 7 possible outcomes, all shown with pictures.The object is to remove all the fruit from your tree first. The spinner tells you if you can take 1, 2, 3, or 4 fruits off, and has other options like lose a turn and having to put all your fruit back on the tree. Simple stuff.There is zero strategy. It's all luck of the spinner.It's not so nightmarishly simple so that it's painful for adults to play with kids. But it won't entral you like Monoply will either. (Also your kids will win this more than Monopoloy. So if you hate losing to you kids...well....)What games like this are great for is teaching small children how to follow rules. This is a very rule based game with no strategy. So it's all about following the rules. This is a great way to teach kids how to do this, which is a valuable lesson for obvious reasons.

review_title: My kids' favorite game. It comes with extra cherries just in ...
review_description: My kids' favorite game.  It comes with extra cherries just in case.  It's taught my 2 year old to count...yet my 8 year old enjoys playing it...not too baby-ish.  Makes for fun on a rainy day or for family game night.  Easy for kids to play & learn.

review_title: Slightly different than the original game in the sense not ...
review_description: Slightly different than the original game in the sense not every players “cherries” are red. All the little plastic pieces look the same (cherries) except there is the Apple tree (green); blueberry tree (blue); orange tree(orange/yellowish); and cherry tree (red). Daughter age 4 loves it.

review_title: I'm very disappointed that this product does not have any orange pieces ...
review_description: I'm very disappointed that this product does not have any orange pieces and only supports three players.  I contacted Hasbro Games asking for the orange pieces so my family of four can play the game and this is what they told me:"Regrettably the version with orange fruit is no longer in production and replacement parts are no longer available.  Since your satisfaction is our goal, I am sending you our revised Hi Ho Cherry O game to the address you've provided. Please note, the replacement game is for up to 3 players only."I appreciate their effort to keep me satisfied and if they replacement pieces work with our existing game, we'll just throw all the pieces together.  I just wish I'd know the box was incorrectly labeled (it indicated four colors, including orange, and that the game allows for four players, which ours does without additional pieces) before I bought and opened it.Hasbro's effort to keep me happy is the only reason I gave the game three stars instead of one.  It was a hassle to have to contact Hasbro Games and sort this out, but my daughters still enjoy playing the game with me and the idea is great.  Just be warned that the box is incorrectly labeled and only supports three players.

review_title: Good game very similar to the original. Required assembly was a bit more than it should be. Game play still the same as always.
review_description: Good game, very similar to what I remember from my childhood, with the primary difference being that there are now four different fruit (blue berries, cherries, green apples, and oranges) rather than just all cherries, which can be somewhat of a pain since now you have to sort out the fruit when setting up. Not a big deal though.The game came in quite the unassembled state, which while not a huge deal, I was a bit disappointed by the fact that even the game board required me to fold all four sides down and tape them (no tape was provided) to set the game board in its elevated state. I ended up actually using a hot glue gun rather than tape. I also used the hot glue gun to adhere the spinner base to the bottom of the spinner card, ensuring the spinner would operate more reliably.I would like to have seen the game come with at least the board properly built, and I would also have liked to see the game built such that the spinner mounts in the middle of the main game board, rather than being its own separate entity that must be passed around. If memory serves, that was how the original game I played in my youth was designed.Otherwise, the directions were clearly written, there was a new game play version focusing on cooperative play that employs the use of an included puzzle to provide the "competition", which may eventually be an enjoyable alternative version (we haven't played that version yet), and the graphics were decent and not overbearing like so many other of the modern remakes of classic kids' board games.The final say on the game: my 3 year old daughter loves it.

This is a fun game to help challenge the kids with their math skills.  The game is fun but it probably wont last long as there are several poor features that take away from the long time use of the game.  Maybe this version of the game will be updated one day but I probably could have constructed my own version of this game with my own construction or card stock paper.  There are several small pieces with this game so please be careful with allowing small toddlers to play with it.  It's a classic game but it definitely needs to have its features upgraded.

This game was a disappointment. I bought it because my 4yo is about to age out of his occupational therapy, and he's not holding a pen / pencil yet. But the tediousness of setup with this game, the ease of disturbing pieces after set up, and the fact that the play is so rote that my 4 year old has lost interest before the game is over (not usual for him) make this a game I don't think we'll play much. Even the collaborative version of play seemed boring (and we NEVER landed on the bird, so we didn't even get to start to put the puzzle together). What a waste. I just did some more research and am watching videos of games being played this time before buying them. There ARE games that exist that can engage tiny hands / big hands alike, which I think would be more fun for him... I prefer he learns a game that doesn't "talk down" to him. In any case, if you have a kid who just likes to organize little pieces, this game is for you!

review_title: Fun for 2.5 years old and up!
review_description: I bought this to play with my daughter and she loves it! She got it when she was 2 and 7 months and was able to learn how to play it pretty quickly (less than a week). Now she's almost 3 and she understands it completely! It teaches to take turns and practice counting. Although there isn't a strategy here (just spin and hope for the best) it's not too dull for me and I enjoy playing it with her.The only downside is there are small parts, so if you have younger babies at home keep an eye out and put this up high when done ao you don't have a chocking hazard.

review_title: A nice game but the quality could be better
review_description: A simple but fun game. The rules are easy to learn and follow and my daughter enjoys it. Two downsides for me - they playing pieces or ‘cherries’ are really small so very easy to lose. The second - and biggest - negative though is the playing board is super flimsy. It’s a folded box of very thin card which bends and breaks very easily - especially when my young child is paying with it and doesn’t yet have a concept of her own strength. It’s a shame the board isn’t made of something stronger otherwise this would be a 4 or even 5 star review.

review_title: Where was this game when I was little?
review_description: My daughter's 4, and the only board game she's really played much of is Candyland. I never played Hi Ho Cherry-O when I was little, but based on the things I've read, it seemed like a safe bet. I mean hey, she has orange hair and loves dogs, so she was already interested based on the box art alone. We played this for a good 30 minutes the other day and she really enjoyed it, though she still hates losing of course...Hi Ho Cherry-O is easy to play and set up. Up to 4 people can play, with each person having their own tree or bush to pick fruit from. You have cherries, blueberries, oranges and green apples, and 10 of each fruit are on each tree. Players take turns spinning an arrow that will land on either a number, a bird, a dog or a basket. If it lands on a number, they take that many of their fruit from the tree and put it in their basket. If it lands on the bird or dog, the animal 'eats' one piece of fruit and the player has to put it back on the tree. And if the arrow lands on the basket? They lose ALL their fruit and have to put every piece back on the tree! The first person to get 10 pieces of fruit wins.Like I said, the game is very easy to understand, and kids 3-5 will probably get the most out of it, counting the pieces of fruit whenever the arrow lands on the number. It's a fun game to play, and sometimes a game will take longer than you'd think if you constantly get the basket or either animal. I couldn't believe it when I got the dog and bird 7 times in a row, and my daughter got the basket three times in one game, so close to winning each time, only to have me finally win when I started to get numbers. She wasn't too happy with that.The only bad thing I can say about this game is that the construction is on the wimpy side. Several people have complained about the game board being flimsy, and I have to agree, though I just had the game box hold the board so it was more stable, and we played without any problems. It's somewhat thin though, and I can see it getting all bent up if hyper kids use it, but it all depends on the people using it. You get 11 of each fruit piece- 10 to put in the trees and 1 extra of each, which is great of them to do, but I can't help but wonder if 5 extra pieces would've been a safer choice given how easy it is to lose things of this size. Just be careful when playing and keep checking to make sure everyone has their pieces and you should be good.What more can I say? I highly recommend this game and wish it were around when I was little. But noooo...I was stuck with the panic attack-inducing Perfection instead.

i get that its a classic game but 15$ for this stuff? all it got is a card board and 40 plastic cherries( coloured cherries?) .. its dollar store quality... i wouldn’t spend more than 3$ for this game... i have ordered many board games over a span of 7 yrs and I have ordered one more board game from eric crale hungry catterpillar series whichia of wonderful quality and is a better game which helps counting,colors, technique and puzzles... pls build stuff that is worrh the money that you are asking for... u want to build a simple game? sure but wheres the quality?

review_title: Great therapy game for kids with behavioral problems!
review_description: This game is great for for the whole family and for little ones! It teaches them how to count and patience. Also teaches them about controlling their behavior if they have to put some back on the board, if they get angry over things like that. My sons behavior therapist likes to play this game with him because of that purpose.

review_title: Fun to Play with your little ones
review_description: This game can go quick or take a while. It's just a matter of luck. You start off with 10 Cherries on your tree and spin the wheel to remove them (or not) and first person to collect all their cherries win! There's a new addition of a puzzle but we haven't played with that yet. My 5 year old loves this game. It might be more fun with more than two players but we've only played with the two of us so we usually do about 3 games at a time.

Great game for ages 2 +. My 2 year old loves it and plays it everyday. It’s great to teach counting and sorting colors. She also loves putting the small puzzle together which is small enough for a 2 year old to do on their own. I would use caution if you have a small child that tends to put things in their mouth. The tiny fruit pieces might look like candy to them. My little one doesn’t usually do this, but when we first got the game she pretended to bite the tiny fruit pieces. I had to warn her not to actually put them in her mouth!

Yikes!  My toddler likes to take  the itty bitty fruits and throw them all over the floor!  The part of the board he likes best are the holes he was able to punch.  However, you can't re-punch the holes.  It's just a place to rest your fruits  before you plop them in the basket.Lame. Boring.  Messy.

Got this and candyland as a gift for our 3 year old. Candyland requires too much focus right now, but this game is quick and easy. Keeps them focused and helps them learn to take turns and count. But most of all, he and his little cousin just want to sort the colored cherries.

This game arrived as shown, and includes 4 colors of fruits, 4 baskets, a spinner, and a bird puzzle (for cooperative play).  There were 10 pieces of every color fruit plus extras (1 extra of each color, except for green of which I got 3 extras).  The game board is made of sturdy cardboard.

This game has so many small pieces that are easy to lose. We lost some fruits after a couple of days so make sure to put the game away right after playing. The game is very easy to learn but can be quite repetitive. My 4 year old daughter likes the game, but it didn’t last long because we lost some pieces.

review_title: wish I had keep mine from when I was a kid
review_description: Got this for my great niece for her 3rd birthday.  Maybe she will get better at it.  She would rather land on the bird than any thing else!  The spinner is very cheaply made.  It keeps coming apart.  I do not expect this game to last long.  It does come with one or two extra apples of each color.

Not so good for little ones pieces are really small for 3 year olds.  Made cheaply. One good thing I like is the different colors. Not a fan of the puzzle pieces to the game. I would stick with the retro version as the qulaity here is not so good.

review_title: Great game, if my toddler would stop throwing the marbles everywhere
review_description: This game creates a mess that takes a lot of time to clean up.  Multiple times a day, every day the little marble fruits go all over the place, under couches, all over the floor and under tables.  My toddler loves it.  I put it on a shelf.

We've been looking for cooperative games for our 3 year old, so we ordered this. She LOVES this game! It combines counting and turn-taking, which she is now doing really well with. The directions are easy to follow. When we have guests over, she even teaches people how to play the game.

review_title: Good game for very little ones
review_description: My 3- and 5-year-old mostly enjoy this game. It's a good beginner game to teach kids about winning and losing. It's also good for getting them away from the TV.

Fun little game for 5 and inder set. Pieces are a bit small, but for the price it's workable. Kids enjoy these simple games. I would suggest organizing the pieces upon opening, to ensure you will jave all the pieces going forward.

My kids like this game. Each player gets one fruit such as apple or grape and places 10 of that fruit on their tree. Then they try to collect the fruit in their basket to win the game. It's nice that it comes with extra pieces

This game was a saving grace for us during the COVID lockdown. For about 5 days....then my one and a half year old got a hold of the spinner and broke it!  Unfortunately it’s not great quality for the price. It was fun tho!  While it lasted.

My child got for Christmas and keeps wanting to play it over and over again. Good game to play for kids who are learning to play games....instead of some of the ones with so many rules to learn. Plus can't beat the price!

review_title: Great game for early academics and fine motor
review_description: This game is great for my 4-year-old who is working on counting with 1:1 correspondence, and as a relatively easy beginners game, it teaches following directions, etc without being too complicated for little ones. It's also great for fine motor development because you have to set up, manipulate, etc. the super small fruit. My son loves it and I like that he's working on important skills without realizing it. For those who are die-hard fans of this game from their childhood, note that they changed the color of the fruits (instead of everyone having red cherries, each player has a different colored fruit like blueberries, red cherries, etc.). I don't care, but somebody might?

review_title: Great for young kids as it doesn't take any thinking
review_description: Very very very simple game I would say for ages 3-6?  That is my personal opinion.  I gave it as a gift cause the reviews were so good but when I went over and played it I was kinda shocked that there was nothing more to it.

review_title: More then the game you remember as a child
review_description: This version of Hi-Ho Cherry-O is more than I ever remember it being when I was a youth.  "Back in the day" when you played the game there was a distinct winner, and you CAN still play the game that way; however, to accommodate the sore losers, they have a collaborative playing option.  Good I suppose if you want to teach math skills without the drama of someone's feelings being hurt...?  Personally, I took the risk and played the game with my 4 year-old daughter the traditional way so she could learn that sometimes you win and sometimes you don't - how to be gracious if you do win and how to be tolerant if you aren't so lucky.  Overall a fun, simple game.

My granddaughter picked the game up easily and we played it over and over. It was so fun because I had this game as a child and I loved it very much. It was great to play it again with my granddaughter.
Three year old loves it and has no trouble following the directions. Very small parts that get everywhere, so if you have have younger sibs, that can be problematic. Teaches counting to 10 very well.

My son is 3.5 and loves counting. He absolutely LOVES this game. He received it for Christmas and we’ve probably played it 40 times since! Very pleased! Super easy to teach him and it keeps his attention. He loves that we can switch up what color we are too(though he tends to favor the oranges)!
Thought this would be a good gift since it has been around so long. The problem is that the pieces are so small. Easy to swallow or stick up a tiny nose! Maybe better for older kids. Mine are 3 & 4.

review_title: Not the same game from my childhood.  OK if you make up your own rules and don't move the board
review_description: Not the same game from my childhood.  No standing plastic trees with hook stem cherries.  It's a flat cardboard game with holes punched in the picture of the trees where the cherries sit.  If someone (I'm not naming names) accidentally knocks the board, cherries go rolling (a problem for my active 5 yo niece and 4 yo nephew)  We couldn't play as the rules describe because so many spins land on spots that result in all cherries being removed from the tree  (we were going no where fast).  But it did keep my niece and nephew entertained for an hour or so... mostly just picking up and rearranging the little cherries in their holes and baskets.
Was using the restroom and my daughter, almost 5, choked on a plastic cherry.  Very small parts.  There is a warning on the box, not for children under 3.  Shes almost 5.

review_title: Don’t pay full price for this.
review_description: We paid $7 for this and that’s about what it’s worth. If I paid full price, I would be extremely disappointed. It’s just flimsy cardboard and won’t hold up to much up to much play. The “fruits” are smaller than previous versions of the game.

The game is still the same, but I prefer the original where all the cherries/fruits are the same color and same fruit. Having a variety of fruit trees just makes things more confusing for the kids and gives them one more thing to fight over.
Great for preschoolers who can count 1-10 and/or need practice in doing so.  Very small fruits so watch those tiny mouths.  Good practice in taking care of games and keeping all pieces together .
I got this for my son for Christmas. He is 3.5 and he loves it. Very easy for him to understand the concept and how to play and goes fast enough that the game kept his interest until finished.
DO NOT BUY!!!THE WORST!  HUNDREDS of teeny tiny cherries. This game is not ok for ANY children. DO NOT BUY!I opened, looked at all the pieces and threw it away.
Great classic game for Family Game Night! Easy to learn and now there’s a new puzzle option that comes with the game to make it a little harder for older children. Lots of fun!

review_title: Perfect early game for 4 year old
review_description: My 4 year old is enjoying this game. It's great to learning taking turns and counting.  We haven't done the version with the puzzle, but that will give us a new way to play later on.

review_title: Not a very fun game. Just too tedious to set up and ...
review_description: Not a very fun game. Just too tedious to set up and then not that exciting to play. Not worth the work involved in keeping all the tiny cherries in place. The cherries are tiny!

Cute game. Very simple. But really only makes the kids count up to 4 (the highest number you can “spin”.) Therefor it was WAY too simple for my 4 year old. I was hoping for counting up to 20.I just had a baby so I’ll keep it for him.

review_title: Ho Ho Cherry-0 was not the pits
review_description: Thought the game was well designed and appropriate for children under 5.  Object of game is to spin the spinner on your turn and follow the instructions on the spinner board and remove the cherries from your tree before your opponents. First player to remove cherries from the tree is the winner.  All players can play together in a cooperative version as the "house" player (the board) tries to complete a puzzle before all the players remover their cherries from the tree. There are a lot of little pieces (plastic fruit) to store but it was fun and very simple to play in terms of rules.....
